text: 28 Joan Foretells Her Doom
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: THE TROOPS must have a rest. Two days would be allowed for this.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The morning of the 14th I was writing from Joan's dictation in a small
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: room which she sometimes used as a private office when she wanted to get
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: away from officials and their interruptions. Catherine Boucher came in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and sat down and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, dear, I want you to talk to me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Indeed, I am not sorry for that, but glad. What is in your mind?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "This. I scarcely slept last night, for thinking of the dangers you are
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: running. The Paladin told me how you made the duke stand out of the way
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: when the cannon-balls were flying all about, and so saved his life."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, that was right, wasn't it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Right? Yes; but you stayed there yourself. Why will you do like that?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It seems such a wanton risk."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, no, it was not so. I was not in any danger."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "How can you say that, Joan, with those deadly things flying all about
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: you?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan laughed, and tried to turn the subject, but Catherine persisted.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It was horribly dangerous, and it could not be necessary to stay
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in such a place. And you led an assault again. Joan, it is tempting
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Providence. I want you to make me a promise. I want you to promise me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that you will let others lead the assaults, if there must be assaults,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and that you will take better care of yourself in those dreadful
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: battles. Will you?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But Joan fought away from the promise and did not give it. Catherine sat
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: troubled and discontented awhile, then she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, are you going to be a soldier always? These wars are so long--so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: long. They last forever and ever and ever."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was a glad flash in Joan's eye as she cried:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "This campaign will do all the really hard work that is in front of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it in the next four days. The rest of it will be gentler--oh, far less
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bloody. Yes, in four days France will gather another trophy like the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: redemption of Orleans and make her second long step toward freedom!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Catherine started (and so did I); then she gazed long at Joan like one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in a trance, murmuring "four days--four days," as if to herself and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: unconsciously. Finally she asked, in a low voice that had something of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: awe in it:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, tell me--how is it that you know that? For you do know it, I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: think."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes," said Joan, dreamily, "I know--I know. I shall strike--and strike
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: again. And before the fourth day is finished I shall strike yet again."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She became silent. We sat wondering and still. This was for a whole
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: minute, she looking at the floor and her lips moving but uttering
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: nothing. Then came these words, but hardly audible: "And in a thousand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: years the English power in France will not rise up from that blow."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It made my flesh creep. It was uncanny. She was in a trance again--I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could see it--just as she was that day in the pastures of Domremy when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she prophesied about us boys in the war and afterward did not know that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she had done it. She was not conscious now; but Catherine did not know
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that, and so she said, in a happy voice:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, I believe it, I believe it, and I am so glad! Then you will come
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: back and bide with us all your life long, and we will love you so, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: honor you!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: A scarcely perceptible spasm flitted across Joan's face, and the dreamy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: voice muttered:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Before two years are sped I shall die a cruel death!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I sprang forward with a warning hand up. That is why Catherine did not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: scream. She was going to do that--I saw it plainly. Then I whispered her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to slip out of the place, and say nothing of what had happened. I said
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan was asleep--asleep and dreaming. Catherine whispered back, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, I am so grateful that it is only a dream! It sounded like
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: prophecy." And she was gone.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Like prophecy! I knew it was prophecy; and I sat down crying, as knowing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: we should lose her. Soon she started, shivering slightly, and came to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: herself, and looked around and saw me crying there, and jumped out of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her chair and ran to me all in a whirl of sympathy and compassion, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: put her hand on my head, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "My poor boy! What is it? Look up and tell me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I had to tell her a lie; I grieved to do it, but there was no other way.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I picked up an old letter from my table, written by Heaven knows who,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: about some matter Heaven knows what, and told her I had just gotten it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: from Pere Fronte, and that in it it said the children's Fairy Tree had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: been chopped down by some miscreant or other, and-- I got no further.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She snatched the letter from my hand and searched it up and down and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: all over, turning it this way and that, and sobbing great sobs, and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tears flowing down her cheeks, and ejaculating all the time, "Oh, cruel,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: cruel! how could any be so heartless? Ah, poor Arbre Fee de Bourlemont
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: gone--and we children loved it so! Show me the place where it says it!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And I, still lying, showed her the pretended fatal words on the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pretended fatal page, and she gazed at them through her tears, and said
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she could see herself that they were hateful, ugly words--they "had the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: very look of it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then we heard a strong voice down the corridor announcing:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "His majesty's messenger--with despatches for her Excellency the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Commander-in-Chief of the Armies of France!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 29 Fierce Talbot Reconsiders
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I KNEW she had seen the wisdom of the Tree. But when? I could not know.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Doubtless before she had lately told the King to use her, for that she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had but one year left to work in. It had not occurred to me at the time,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but the conviction came upon me now that at that time she had already
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: seen the Tree. It had brought her a welcome message; that was plain,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: otherwise she could not have been so joyous and light-hearted as she had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: been these latter days. The death-warning had nothing dismal about it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: for her; no, it was remission of exile, it was leave to come home.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, she had seen the Tree. No one had taken the prophecy to heart which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she made to the King; and for a good reason, no doubt; no one wanted to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: take it to heart; all wanted to banish it away and forget it. And all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had succeeded, and would go on to the end placid and comfortable. All
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but me alone. I must carry my awful secret without any to help me. A
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heavy load, a bitter burden; and would cost me a daily heartbreak. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was to die; and so soon. I had never dreamed of that. How could I, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she so strong and fresh and young, and every day earning a new right
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to a peaceful and honored old age? For at that time I thought old age
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: valuable. I do not know why, but I thought so. All young people think
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it, I believe, they being ignorant and full of superstitions. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had seen the Tree. All that miserable night those ancient verses went
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: floating back and forth through my brain:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And when, in exile wand'ring, we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Shall fainting yearn for glimpse of thee,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Oh, rise upon our sight!

author: Twain, Mark

text: But at dawn the bugles and the drums burst through the dreamy hush of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the French, was in command. When we arrived at that place, the English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: retired into the castle and we sat down in the abandoned town.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: watch for and welcome Fastolfe and his reinforcement of five thousand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: men.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: news came: Richemont, Constable of France, this long time in disgrace
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with the King, largely because of the evil machinations of La Tremouille
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and his party, was approaching with a large body of men to offer his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was so close by. Richemont had wanted to join us before, when we first
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: marched on Orleans; but the foolish King, slave of those paltry advisers
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of his, warned him to keep his distance and refused all reconciliation
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I go into these details because they are important. Important because
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: they lead up to the exhibition of a new gift in Joan's extraordinary
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mental make-up--statesmanship. It is a sufficiently strange thing to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: find that great quality in an ignorant country-girl of seventeen and a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: half, but she had it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan was for receiving Richemont cordially, and so was La Hire and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the two young Lavals and other chiefs, but the Lieutenant-General,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: d'Alencon, strenuously and stubbornly opposed it. He said he had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: absolute orders from the King to deny and defy Richemont, and that if
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: they were overridden he would leave the army. This would have been a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heavy disaster, indeed. But Joan set herself the task of persuading him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that the salvation of France took precedence of all minor things--even
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: him to disobey the King in the interest of the nation, and to be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and of the highest and soundest sort. Whatever thing men call great,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: look for it in Joan of Arc, and there you will find it.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: troops behind to watch the castle of Beaugency and keep its garrison
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: at home. By and by we came in sight of the enemy. Fastolfe had tried to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with Joan at this time, but distribute the new levies among the English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

text: Before dawn we were with our army again, and with us the Constable
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and nearly all his men, for we left only a small garrison in Beaugency
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: castle. We heard the dull booming of cannon to the front, and knew that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Talbot was beginning his attack on the bridge. But some time before it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was yet light the sound ceased and we heard it no more.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Guetin had sent a messenger through our lines under a safe-conduct given
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: by Joan, to tell Talbot of the surrender. Of course this poursuivant had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: arrived ahead of us. Talbot had held it wisdom to turn now and retreat
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon Paris. When daylight came he had disappeared; and with him Lord
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Scales and the garrison of Meung.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: What a harvest of English strongholds we had reaped in those three
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: days!--strongholds which had defied France with quite cool confidence
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and plenty of it until we came.

author: Twain, Mark

text: 30 The Red Field of Patay
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: WHEN THE morning broke at last on that forever memorable 18th of June,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: there was no enemy discoverable anywhere, as I have said. But that did
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not trouble me. I knew we should find him, and that we should strike
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: him; strike him the promised blow--the one from which the English power
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in France would not rise up in a thousand years, as Joan had said in her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: trance.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The enemy had plunged into the wide plains of La Beauce--a roadless
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: waste covered with bushes, with here and there bodies of forest trees--a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: region where an army would be hidden from view in a very little while.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We found the trail in the soft wet earth and followed it. It indicated
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: an orderly march; no confusion, no panic.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But we had to be cautious. In such a piece of country we could walk into
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: an ambush without any trouble. Therefore Joan sent bodies of cavalry
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ahead under La Hire, Pothon, and other captains, to feel the way.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Some of the other officers began to show uneasiness; this sort of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hide-and-go-seek business troubled them and made their confidence
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a little shaky. Joan divined their state of mind and cried out
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: impetuously:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Name of God, what would you? We must smite these English, and we will.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: They shall not escape us. Though they were hung to the clouds we would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: get them!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: By and by we were nearing Patay; it was about a league away. Now at this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: time our reconnaissance, feeling its way in the bush, frightened a deer,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and it went bounding away and was out of sight in a moment. Then hardly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a minute later a dull great shout went up in the distance toward Patay.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was the English soldiery. They had been shut up in a garrison so long
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: on moldy food that they could not keep their delight to themselves when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: this fine fresh meat came springing into their midst. Poor creature, it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had wrought damage to a nation which loved it well. For the French knew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: where the English were now, whereas the English had no suspicion of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: where the French were.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: La Hire halted where he was, and sent back the tidings. Joan was radiant
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with joy. The Duke d'Alencon said to her:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Very well, we have found them; shall we fight them?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Have you good spurs, prince?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Why? Will they make us run away?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Nenni, en nom de Dieu! These English are ours--they are lost. They will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fly. Who overtakes them will need good spurs. Forward--close up!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: By the time we had come up with La Hire the English had discovered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: our presence. Talbot's force was marching in three bodies. First his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: advance-guard; then his artillery; then his battle-corps a good way in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the rear. He was now out of the bush and in a fair open country. He at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: once posted his artillery, his advance-guard, and five hundred picked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: archers along some hedges where the French would be obliged to pass,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and hoped to hold this position till his battle-corps could come up.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Sir John Fastolfe urged the battle-corps into a gallop. Joan saw her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: opportunity and ordered La Hire to advance--which La Hire promptly did,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: launching his wild riders like a storm-wind, his customary fashion.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The duke and the Bastard wanted to follow, but Joan said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Not yet--wait."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: So they waited--impatiently, and fidgeting in their saddles. But she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ready--gazing straight before her, measuring, weighing, calculating--by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: shades, minutes, fractions of minutes, seconds--with all her great soul
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: present, in eye, and set of head, and noble pose of body--but patient,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: steady, master of herself--master of herself and of the situation.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And yonder, receding, receding, plumes lifting and falling, lifting and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: falling, streamed the thundering charge of La Hire's godless crew, La
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Hire's great figure dominating it and his sword stretched aloft like a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: flagstaff.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, Satan and his Hellions, see them go!" Somebody muttered it in deep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: admiration.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And now he was closing up--closing up on Fastolfe's rushing corps.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And now he struck it--struck it hard, and broke its order. It lifted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the duke and the Bastard in their saddles to see it; and they turned,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: trembling with excitement, to Joan, saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But she put up her hand, still gazing, weighing, calculating, and said
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: again:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Wait--not yet."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Fastolfe's hard-driven battle-corps raged on like an avalanche toward
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the waiting advance-guard. Suddenly these conceived the idea that it was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: flying in panic before Joan; and so in that instant it broke and swarmed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: away in a mad panic itself, with Talbot storming and cursing after it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now was the golden time. Joan drove her spurs home and waved the advance
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with her sword. "Follow me!" she cried, and bent her head to her horse's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: neck and sped away like the wind!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We went down into the confusion of that flying rout, and for three long
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hours we cut and hacked and stabbed. At last the bugles sang "Halt!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Battle of Patay was won.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan of Arc dismounted, and stood surveying that awful field, lost in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: thought. Presently she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The praise is to God. He has smitten with a heavy hand this day."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: After a little she lifted her face, and looking afar off, said, with the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: manner of one who is thinking aloud, "In a thousand years--a thousand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: years--the English power in France will not rise up from this blow."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She stood again a time thinking, then she turned toward her grouped
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: generals, and there was a glory in her face and a noble light in her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: eye; and she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, friends, friends, do you know?--do you comprehend? France is on the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: way to be free!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And had never been, but for Joan of Arc!" said La Hire, passing before
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her and bowing low, the other following and doing likewise; he muttering
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: as he went, "I will say it though I be damned for it." Then battalion
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: after battalion of our victorious army swung by, wildly cheering. And
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: they shouted, "Live forever, Maid of Orleans, live forever!" while Joan,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: smiling, stood at the salute with her sword.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: This was not the last time I saw the Maid of Orleans on the red field
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of Patay. Toward the end of the day I came upon her where the dead and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dying lay stretched all about in heaps and winrows; our men had mortally
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: wounded an English prisoner who was too poor to pay a ransom, and from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a distance she had seen that cruel thing done; and had galloped to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: place and sent for a priest, and now she was holding the head of her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dying enemy in her lap, and easing him to his death with comforting soft
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: words, just as his sister might have done; and the womanly tears running
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: down her face all the time. (1)
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: 31 France Begins to Live Again
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: JOAN HAD said true: France was on the way to be free.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The war called the Hundred Years' War was very sick to-day. Sick on its
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: English side--for the very first time since its birth, ninety-one years
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: gone by.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Shall we judge battles by the numbers killed and the ruin wrought? Or
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: shall we not rather judge them by the results which flowed from them?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Any one will say that a battle is only truly great or small according to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: its results. Yes, any one will grant that, for it is the truth.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Judged by results, Patay's place is with the few supremely great and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: imposing battles that have been fought since the peoples of the world
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: first resorted to arms for the settlement of their quarrels. So
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: judged, it is even possible that Patay has no peer among that few just
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mentioned, but stand alone, as the supremest of historic conflicts. For
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: when it began France lay gasping out the remnant of an exhausted life,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her case wholly hopeless in the view of all political physicians; when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it ended, three hours later, she was convalescent. Convalescent, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: nothing requisite but time and ordinary nursing to bring her back to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: perfect health. The dullest physician of them all could see this, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: there was none to deny it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Many death-sick nations have reached convalescence through a series
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of battles, a procession of battles, a weary tale of wasting conflicts
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stretching over years, but only one has reached it in a single day and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: by a single battle. That nation is France, and that battle Patay.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Remember it and be proud of it; for you are French, and it is the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stateliest fact in the long annals of your country. There it stands,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with its head in the clouds! And when you grow up you will go on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pilgrimage to the field of Patay, and stand uncovered in the presence
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of--what? A monument with its head in the clouds? Yes. For all nations
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in all times have built monuments on their battle-fields to keep green
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the memory of the perishable deed that was wrought there and of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: perishable name of him who wrought it; and will France neglect Patay and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan of Arc? Not for long. And will she build a monument scaled to their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: rank as compared with the world's other fields and heroes? Perhaps--if
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: there be room for it under the arch of the sky.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But let us look back a little, and consider certain strange and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: impressive facts. The Hundred Years' War began in 1337. It raged on and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: on, year after year and year after year; and at last England stretched
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: France prone with that fearful blow at Crecy. But she rose and struggled
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: on, year after year, and at last again she went down under another
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: devastating blow--Poitiers. She gathered her crippled strength once
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: more, and the war raged on, and on, and still on, year after year,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: decade after decade. Children were born, grew up, married, died--the war
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: raged on; their children in turn grew up, married, died--the war raged
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: on; their children, growing, saw France struck down again; this time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: under the incredible disaster of Agincourt--and still the war raged on,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: year after year, and in time these children married in their turn.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: France was a wreck, a ruin, a desolation. The half of it belonged to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: England, with none to dispute or deny the truth; the other half belonged
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to nobody--in three months would be flying the English flag; the French
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: King was making ready to throw away his crown and flee beyond the seas.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now came the ignorant country-maid out of her remote village and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: confronted this hoary war, this all-consuming conflagration that had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: swept the land for three generations. Then began the briefest and most
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: amazing campaign that is recorded in history. In seven weeks it was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: finished. In seven weeks she hopelessly crippled that gigantic war that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was ninety-one years old. At Orleans she struck it a staggering blow; on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the field of Patay she broke its back.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Think of it. Yes, one can do that; but understand it? Ah, that is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: another matter; none will ever be able to comprehend that stupefying
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: marvel.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Seven weeks--with her and there a little bloodshed. Perhaps the most of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it, in any single fight, at Patay, where the English began six thousand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong and left two thousand dead upon the field. It is said
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and believed that in three battles alone--Crecy, Poitiers, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Agincourt--near a hundred thousand Frenchmen fell, without counting
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the thousand other fights of that long war. The dead of that war make a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mournful long list--an interminable list. Of men slain in the field the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: count goes by tens of thousands; of innocent women and children slain by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bitter hardship and hunger it goes by that appalling term, millions.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was an ogre, that war; an ogre that went about for near a hundred
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: years, crunching men and dripping blood from its jaws. And with her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: little hand that child of seventeen struck him down; and yonder he lies
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stretched on the field of Patay, and will not get up any more while this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: old world lasts.

author: Twain, Mark

text: 32 The Joyous News Flies Fast
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: THE GREAT news of Patay was carried over the whole of France in twenty
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hours, people said. I do not know as to that; but one thing is sure,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: anyway: the moment a man got it he flew shouting and glorifying God and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: told his neighbor; and that neighbor flew with it to the next homestead;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and so on and so on without resting the word traveled; and when a man
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: got it in the night, at what hour soever, he jumped out of his bed and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bore the blessed message along. And the joy that went with it was like
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the light that flows across the land when an eclipse is receding from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the face of the sun; and, indeed, you may say that France had lain in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: an eclipse this long time; yes, buried in a black gloom which these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: beneficent tidings were sweeping away now before the onrush of their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: white splendor.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The news beat the flying enemy to Yeuville, and the town rose against
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: its English masters and shut the gates against their brethren. It flew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to Mont Pipeau, to Saint Simon, and to this, that, and the other English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fortress; and straightway the garrison applied the torch and took to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the fields and the woods. A detachment of our army occupied Meung and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pillaged it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: When we reached Orleans that tow was as much as fifty times insaner with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: joy than we had ever seen it before--which is saying much. Night had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: just fallen, and the illuminations were on so wonderful a scale that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: we seemed to plow through seas of fire; and as to the noise--the hoarse
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: cheering of the multitude, the thundering of cannon, the clash of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bells--indeed, there was never anything like it. And everywhere rose
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a new cry that burst upon us like a storm when the column entered the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: gates, and nevermore ceased: "Welcome to Joan of Arc--way for the SAVIOR
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: OF FRANCE!" And there was another cry: "Crecy is avenged! Poitiers is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: avenged! Agincourt is avenged!--Patay shall live forever!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Mad? Why, you never could imagine it in the world. The prisoners were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the center of the column. When that came along and the people caught
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sight of their masterful old enemy Talbot, that had made them dance so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: long to his grim war-music, you may imagine what the uproar was like if
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: you can, for I can not describe it. They were so glad to see him that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: presently they wanted to have him out and hang him; so Joan had him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: brought up to the front to ride in her protection. They made a striking
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pair.

author: Twain, Mark
