text: 33 Joan's Five Great Deeds
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: YES, ORLEANS was in a delirium of felicity. She invited the King, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: made sumptuous preparations to receive him, but--he didn't come. He was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: simply a serf at that time, and La Tremouille was his master. Master and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: serf were visiting together at the master's castle of Sully-sur-Loire.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: At Beaugency Joan had engaged to bring about a reconciliation
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: between the Constable Richemont and the King. She took Richemont to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Sully-sur-Loire and made her promise good.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The great deeds of Joan of Arc are five:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 1. The Raising of the Siege.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 2. The Victory of Patay.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 3. The Reconciliation at Sully-sur-Loire.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 4. The Coronation of the King.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 5. The Bloodless March.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We shall come to the Bloodless March presently (and the Coronation).
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was the victorious long march which Joan made through the enemy's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: country from Gien to Rheims, and thence to the gates of Paris, capturing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: every English town and fortress that barred the road, from the beginning
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the journey to the end of it; and this by the mere force of her name,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and without shedding a drop of blood--perhaps the most extraordinary
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: campaign in this regard in history--this is the most glorious of her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: military exploits.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Reconciliation was one of Joan's most important achievements. No
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: one else could have accomplished it; and, in fact, no one else of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: high consequence had any disposition to try. In brains, in scientific
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: warfare, and in statesmanship the Constable Richemont was the ablest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: man in France. His loyalty was sincere; his probity was above
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: suspicion--(and it made him sufficiently conspicuous in that trivial and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: conscienceless Court).
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: In restoring Richemont to France, Joan made thoroughly secure the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: successful completion of the great work which she had begun. She had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: never seen Richemont until he came to her with his little army. Was it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not wonderful that at a glance she should know him for the one man who
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could finish and perfect her work and establish it in perpetuity? How
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was it that that child was able to do this? It was because she had the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "seeing eye," as one of our knights had once said. Yes, she had that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: great gift--almost the highest and rarest that has been granted to man.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Nothing of an extraordinary sort was still to be done, yet the remaining
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: work could not safely be left to the King's idiots; for it would require
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: wise statesmanship and long and patient though desultory hammering of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the enemy. Now and then, for a quarter of a century yet, there would be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a little fighting to do, and a handy man could carry that on with small
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: disturbance to the rest of the country; and little by little, and with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: progressive certainty, the English would disappear from France.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And that happened. Under the influence of Richemont the King became at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a later time a man--a man, a king, a brave and capable and determined
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: soldier. Within six years after Patay he was leading storming parties
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: himself; fighting in fortress ditches up to his waist in water, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: climbing scaling-ladders under a furious fire with a pluck that would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: have satisfied even Joan of Arc. In time he and Richemont cleared away
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: all the English; even from regions where the people had been under their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mastership for three hundred years. In such regions wise and careful
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: work was necessary, for the English rule had been fair and kindly; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: men who have been ruled in that way are not always anxious for a change.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Which of Joan's five chief deeds shall we call the chiefest? It is my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: thought that each in its turn was that. This is saying that, taken as a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: whole, they equalized each other, and neither was then greater than its
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mate.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Do you perceive? Each was a stage in an ascent. To leave out one of them
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would defeat the journey; to achieve one of them at the wrong time and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the wrong place would have the same effect.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Consider the Coronation. As a masterpiece of diplomacy, where can
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: you find its superior in our history? Did the King suspect its
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: vast importance? No. Did his ministers? No. Did the astute Bedford,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: representative of the English crown? No. An advantage of incalculable
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: importance was here under the eyes of the King and of Bedford; the King
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could get it by a bold stroke, Bedford could get it without an effort;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but, being ignorant of its value, neither of them put forth his hand.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Of all the wise people in high office in France, only one knew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the priceless worth of this neglected prize--the untaught child of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: seventeen, Joan of Arc--and she had known it from the beginning as an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: essential detail of her mission.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: How did she know it? It was simple: she was a peasant. That tells the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: whole story. She was of the people and knew the people; those others
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: moved in a loftier sphere and knew nothing much about them. We make
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: little account of that vague, formless, inert mass, that mighty
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: underlying force which we call "the people"--an epithet which carries
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: contempt with it. It is a strange attitude; for at bottom we know that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the throne which the people support stands, and that when that support
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: is removed nothing in this world can save it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now, then, consider this fact, and observe its importance. Whatever the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: parish priest believes his flock believes; they love him, they revere
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: him; he is their unfailing friend, their dauntless protector, their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: comforter in sorrow, their helper in their day of need; he has their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: whole confidence; what he tells them to do, that they will do, with a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: blind and affectionate obedience, let it cost what it may. Add these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: facts thoughtfully together, and what is the sum? This: The parish
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: priest governs the nation. What is the King, then, if the parish priest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: withdraws his support and deny his authority? Merely a shadow and no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: King; let him resign.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Do you get that idea? Then let us proceed. A priest is consecrated to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: his office by the awful hand of God, laid upon him by his appointed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: representative on earth. That consecration is final; nothing can undo
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it, nothing can remove it. Neither the Pope nor any other power can
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: strip the priest of his office; God gave it, and it is forever sacred
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and secure. The dull parish knows all this. To priest and parish,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: whatsoever is anointed of God bears an office whose authority can
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: no longer be disputed or assailed. To the parish priest, and to his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: subjects the nation, an uncrowned king is a similitude of a person who
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: has been named for holy orders but has not been consecrated; he has no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: office, he has not been ordained, another may be appointed to his place.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: In a word, an uncrowned king is a doubtful king; but if God appoint him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and His servant the Bishop anoint him, the doubt is annihilated; the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: priest and the parish are his loyal subjects straightway, and while he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: lives they will recognize no king but him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: To Joan of Arc, the peasant-girl, Charles VII. was no King until he was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: crowned; to her he was only the Dauphin; that is to say, the heir. If I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: have ever made her call him King, it was a mistake; she called him the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Dauphin, and nothing else until after the Coronation. It shows you as in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a mirror--for Joan was a mirror in which the lowly hosts of France were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: clearly reflected--that to all that vast underlying force called "the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: people," he was no King but only Dauphin before his crowning, and was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: indisputably and irrevocably King after it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now you understand what a colossal move on the political chess-board the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Coronation was. Bedford realized this by and by, and tried to patch up
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: his mistake by crowning his King; but what good could that do? None in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the world.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Speaking of chess, Joan's great acts may be likened to that game. Each
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: move was made in its proper order, and it as great and effective because
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was made in its proper order and not out of it. Each, at the time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: made, seemed the greatest move; but the final result made them all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: recognizable as equally essential and equally important. This is the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: game, as played:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 1. Joan moves to Orleans and Patay--check.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 2. Then moves the Reconciliation--but does not proclaim check, it being
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a move for position, and to take effect later.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 3. Next she moves the Coronation--check.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 4. Next, the Bloodless March--check.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 5. Final move (after her death), the reconciled Constable Richemont to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the French King's elbow--checkmate.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: 34 The Jests of the Burgundians

author: Twain, Mark

text: THE CAMPAIGN of the Loire had as good as opened the road to Rheims.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was no sufficient reason now why the Coronation should not take
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: place. The Coronation would complete the mission which Joan had received
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: from heaven, and then she would be forever done with war, and would fly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: home to her mother and her sheep, and never stir from the hearthstone
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and happiness any more. That was her dream; and she could not rest, she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was so impatient to see it fulfilled. She became so possessed with this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: matter that I began to lose faith in her two prophecies of her early
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: death--and, of course, when I found that faith wavering I encouraged it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to waver all the more.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The King was afraid to start to Rheims, because the road was mile-posted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with English fortresses, so to speak. Joan held them in light esteem and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not things to be afraid of in the existing modified condition of English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: confidence.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And she was right. As it turned out, the march to Rheims was nothing but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a holiday excursion: Joan did not even take any artillery along, she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: so sure it would not be necessary. We marched from Gien twelve thousand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong. This was the 29th of June. The Maid rode by the side of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: King; on his other side was the Duke d'Alencon. After the duke followed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: three other princes of the blood. After these followed the Bastard of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Orleans, the Marshal de Boussac, and the Admiral of France. After these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: came La Hire, Saintrailles, Tremouille, and a long procession of knights
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and nobles.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We rested three days before Auxerre. The city provisioned the army, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a deputation waited upon the King, but we did not enter the place.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Saint-Florentin opened its gates to the King.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: On the 4th of July we reached Saint-Fal, and yonder lay Troyes before
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: us--a town which had a burning interest for us boys; for we remembered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: how seven years before, in the pastures of Domremy, the Sunflower came
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with his black flag and brought us the shameful news of the Treaty of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Troyes--that treaty which gave France to England, and a daughter of our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: royal line in marriage to the Butcher of Agincourt. That poor town was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not to blame, of course; yet we flushed hot with that old memory, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hoped there would be a misunderstanding here, for we dearly wanted to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: storm the place and burn it. It was powerfully garrisoned by English and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Burgundian soldiery, and was expecting reinforcements from Paris. Before
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: night we camped before its gates and made rough work with a sortie which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: marched out against us.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan summoned Troyes to surrender. Its commandant, seeing that she had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: no artillery, scoffed at the idea, and sent her a grossly insulting
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: reply. Five days we consulted and negotiated. No result. The King was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: about to turn back now and give up. He was afraid to go on, leaving this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong place in his rear. Then La Hire put in a word, with a slap in it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: for some of his Majesty's advisers:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The Maid of Orleans undertook this expedition of her own motion; and it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: is my mind that it is her judgment that should be followed here, and not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that of any other, let him be of whatsoever breed and standing he may."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was wisdom and righteousness in that. So the King sent for the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Maid, and asked her how she thought the prospect looked. She said,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: without any tone of doubt or question in her voice:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "In three days' time the place is ours."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The smug Chancellor put in a word now:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If we were sure of it we would wait her six days."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Six days, forsooth! Name of God, man, we will enter the gates
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to-morrow!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then she mounted, and rode her lines, crying out:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Make preparation--to your work, friends, to your work! We assault at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dawn!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She worked hard that night, slaving away with her own hands like a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: common soldier. She ordered fascines and fagots to be prepared and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: thrown into the fosse, thereby to bridge it; and in this rough labor she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: took a man's share.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: At dawn she took her place at the head of the storming force and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bugles blew the assault. At that moment a flag of truce was flung to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: breeze from the walls, and Troyes surrendered without firing a shot.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The next day the King with Joan at his side and the Paladin bearing her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: banner entered the town in state at the head of the army. And a goodly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: army it was now, for it had been growing ever bigger and bigger from the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: first.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And now a curious thing happened. By the terms of the treaty made with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the town the garrison of English and Burgundian soldiery were to be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: allowed to carry away their "goods" with them. This was well, for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: otherwise how would they buy the wherewithal to live? Very well; these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: people were all to go out by the one gate, and at the time set for them
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to depart we young fellows went to that gate, along with the Dwarf, to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: see the march-out. Presently here they came in an interminable file, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: foot-soldiers in the lead. As they approached one could see that each
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bore a burden of a bulk and weight to sorely tax his strength; and we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: said among ourselves, truly these folk are well off for poor common
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: soldiers. When they were come nearer, what do you think? Every rascal
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of them had a French prisoner on his back! They were carrying away their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "goods," you see--their property--strictly according to the permission
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: granted by the treaty.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now think how clever that was, how ingenious. What could a body say?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: what could a body do? For certainly these people were within their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: right. These prisoners were property; nobody could deny that. My dears,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: if those had been English captives, conceive of the richness of that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: booty! For English prisoners had been scarce and precious for a hundred
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: years; whereas it was a different matter with French prisoners. They had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: been over-abundant for a century. The possessor of a French prisoner
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: did not hold him long for ransom, as a rule, but presently killed him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to save the cost of his keep. This shows you how small was the value of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: such a possession in those times. When we took Troyes a calf was worth
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: thirty francs, a sheep sixteen, a French prisoner eight. It was an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: enormous price for those other animals--a price which naturally seems
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: incredible to you. It was the war, you see. It worked two ways: it made
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: meat dear and prisoners cheap.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Well, here were these poor Frenchmen being carried off. What could we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: do? Very little of a permanent sort, but we did what we could. We sent
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a messenger flying to Joan, and we and the French guards halted the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: procession for a parley--to gain time, you see. A big Burgundian lost
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: his temper and swore a great oath that none should stop him; he would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: go, and would take his prisoner with him. But we blocked him off, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: he saw that he was mistaken about going--he couldn't do it. He exploded
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: into the maddest cursings and revilings, then, and, unlashing his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: prisoner from his back, stood him up, all bound and helpless; then drew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: his knife, and said to us with a light of sarcasting triumph in his eye:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I may not carry him away, you say--yet he is mine, none will dispute
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it. Since I may not convey him hence, this property of mine, there is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: another way. Yes, I can kill him; not even the dullest among you will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: question that right. Ah, you had not thought of that--vermin!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: That poor starved fellow begged us with his piteous eyes to save him;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: then spoke, and said he had a wife and little children at home. Think
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: how it wrung our heartstrings. But what could we do? The Burgundian was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: within his right. We could only beg and plead for the prisoner. Which we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: did. And the Burgundian enjoyed it. He stayed his hand to hear more of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it, and laugh at it. That stung. Then the Dwarf said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Prithee, young sirs, let me beguile him; for when a matter requiring
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: permission is to the fore, I have indeed a gift in that sort, as any
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: will tell you that know me well. You smile; and that is punishment for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: my vanity; and fairly earned, I grant you. Still, if I may toy a little,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: just a little--" saying which he stepped to the Burgundian and began a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fair soft speech, all of goodly and gentle tenor; and in the midst he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mentioned the Maid; and was going on to say how she out of her good
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heart would prize and praise this compassionate deed which he was about
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to-- It was as far as he got. The Burgundian burst into his smooth
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: oration with an insult leveled at Joan of Arc. We sprang forward, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the Dwarf, his face all livid, brushed us aside and said, in a most
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: grave and earnest way:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I crave your patience. Am not I her guard of honor? This is my affair."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And saying this he suddenly shot his right hand out and gripped the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: great Burgundian by the throat, and so held him upright on his feet.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You have insulted the Maid," he said; "and the Maid is France. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tongue that does that earns a long furlough."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: One heard the muffled cracking of bones. The Burgundian's eyes began to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: protrude from their sockets and stare with a leaden dullness at vacancy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The color deepened in his face and became an opaque purple. His hands
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hung down limp, his body collapsed with a shiver, every muscle relaxed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: its tension and ceased from its function. The Dwarf took away his hand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the column of inert mortality sank mushily to the ground.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We struck the bonds from the prisoner and told him he was free. His
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: crawling humbleness changed to frantic joy in a moment, and his ghastly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fear to a childish rage. He flew at that dead corpse and kicked it,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: spat in its face, danced upon it, crammed mud into its mouth, laughing,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: jeering, cursing, and volleying forth indecencies and bestialities like
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a drunken fiend. It was a thing to be expected; soldiering makes few
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: saints. Many of the onlookers laughed, others were indifferent, none
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was surprised. But presently in his mad caperings the freed man capered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: within reach of the waiting file, and another Burgundian promptly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: NOW THESE were nobles, you know, by decree of the King!--these precious
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: old infants. But they did not realize it; they could not be called
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: solid; they were visible facts, and would make a mighty stir in Domremy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Presently something was said about the Coronation, and old D'Arc said
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was going to be a grand thing to be able to say, when they got home,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that they were present in the very town itself when it happened. Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: looked troubled, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, that reminds me. You were here and you didn't send me word. In the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: town, indeed! Why, you could have sat with the other nobles, and been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: welcome; and could have looked upon the crowning itself, and carried
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that home to tell. Ah, why did you use me so, and send me no word?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The old father was embarrassed, now, quite visibly embarrassed, and had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the air of one who does not quite know what to say. But Joan was looking
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: up in his face, her hands upon his shoulders--waiting. He had to speak;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: so presently he drew her to his breast, which was heaving with emotion;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "There, hide your face, child, and let your old father humble himself
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and make his confession. I--I--don't you see, don't you understand?--I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could not know that these grandeurs would not turn your young head--it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Father!"

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And then I was afraid, as remembering that cruel thing I said once in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: my sinful anger. Oh, appointed of God to be a soldier, and the greatest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the land! and in my ignorant anger I said I would drown you with my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: own hands if you unsexed yourself and brought shame to your name and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: family. Ah, how could I ever have said it, and you so good and dear
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: child, and you forgive?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Do you see? Even that poor groping old land-crab, with his skull full of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: pulp, had pride. Isn't it wonderful? And more--he had conscience; he had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a sense of right and wrong, such as it was; he was able to find remorse.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It looks impossible, it looks incredible, but it is not. I believe that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a great many respects like ourselves. And I believe that some day they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
