text: sad and the tears lay near the surface. Once, talking with her good old
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: faithful friend and servant, the Bastard of Orleans, she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, if it might but please God to let me put off this steel raiment
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and go back to my father and my mother, and tend my sheep again with my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sister and my brothers, who would be so glad to see me!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: By the 12th of August we were camped near Dampmartin. Later we had a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: brush with Bedford's rear-guard, and had hopes of a big battle on the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: morrow, but Bedford and all his force got away in the night and went on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: toward Paris.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Charles sent heralds and received the submission of Beauvais. The Bishop
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Pierre Cauchon, that faithful friend and slave of the English, was not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: able to prevent it, though he did his best. He was obscure then, but his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: name was to travel round the globe presently, and live forever in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: curses of France! Bear with me now, while I spit in fancy upon his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: grave.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Compiegne surrendered, and hauled down the English flag. On the 14th we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: camped two leagues from Senlis. Bedford turned and approached, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: took up a strong position. We went against him, but all our efforts to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: beguile him out from his intrenchments failed, though he had promised
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: us a duel in the open field. Night shut down. Let him look out for the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: morning! But in the morning he was gone again.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We entered Compiegne the 18th of August, turning out the English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: garrison and hoisting our own flag.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: On the 23d Joan gave command to move upon Paris. The King and the clique
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: were not satisfied with this, and retired sulking to Senlis, which had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: just surrendered. Within a few days many strong places submitted--Creil,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Pont-Saint-Maxence, Choisy, Gournay-sur-Aronde, Remy, Le
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Neufville-en-Hez, Moguay, Chantilly, Saintines. The English power was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tumbling, crash after crash! And still the King sulked and disapproved,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and was afraid of our movement against the capital.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: On the 26th of August, 1429, Joan camped at St. Denis; in effect, under
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the walls of Paris.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And still the King hung back and was afraid. If we could but have had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: him there to back us with his authority! Bedford had lost heart and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: decided to waive resistance and go an concentrate his strength in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: best and loyalest province remaining to him--Normandy. Ah, if we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could only have persuaded the King to come and countenance us with his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: presence and approval at this supreme moment!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 40 Treachery Conquers Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: COURIER after courier was despatched to the King, and he promised to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: come, but didn't. The Duke d'Alencon went to him and got his promise
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: again, which he broke again. Nine days were lost thus; then he came,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: arriving at St. Denis September 7th.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Meantime the enemy had begun to take heart: the spiritless conduct of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the King could have no other result. Preparations had now been made to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: defend the city. Joan's chances had been diminished, but she and her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: generals considered them plenty good enough yet. Joan ordered the attack
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: for eight o'clock next morning, and at that hour it began.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan placed her artillery and began to pound a strong work which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: protected the gate St. Honor. When it was sufficiently crippled the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: assault was sounded at noon, and it was carried by storm. Then we moved
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: forward to storm the gate itself, and hurled ourselves against it again
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and again, Joan in the lead with her standard at her side, the smoke
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: enveloping us in choking clouds, and the missiles flying over us and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: through us as thick as hail.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: In the midst of our last assault, which would have carried the gate
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sure and given us Paris and in effect France, Joan was struck down by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a crossbow bolt, and our men fell back instantly and almost in a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: panic--for what were they without her? She was the army, herself.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Although disabled, she refused to retire, and begged that a new assault
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: be made, saying it must win; and adding, with the battle-light rising in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her eyes, "I will take Paris now or die!" She had to be carried away by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: force, and this was done by Gaucourt and the Duke d'Alencon.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But her spirits were at the very top notch, now. She was brimming
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with enthusiasm. She said she would be carried before the gate in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: morning, and in half an hour Paris would be ours without any question.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She could have kept her word. About this there was no doubt. But
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she forgot one factor--the King, shadow of that substance named La
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Tremouille. The King forbade the attempt!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: You see, a new Embassy had just come from the Duke of Burgundy, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: another sham private trade of some sort was on foot.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: You would know, without my telling you, that Joan's heart was nearly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: broken. Because of the pain of her wound and the pain at her heart she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: slept little that night. Several times the watchers heard muffled
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sobs from the dark room where she lay at St. Denis, and many times the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: grieving words, "It could have been taken!--it could have been taken!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: which were the only ones she said.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She dragged herself out of bed a day later with a new hope. D'Alencon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had thrown a bridge across the Seine near St. Denis. Might she not cross
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: by that and assault Paris at another point? But the King got wind of it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and broke the bridge down! And more--he declared the campaign ended!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And more still--he had made a new truce and a long one, in which he had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: agreed to leave Paris unthreatened and unmolested, and go back to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Loire whence he had come!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan of Arc, who had never been defeated by the enemy, was defeated by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her own King. She had said once that all she feared for her cause was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: treachery. It had struck its first blow now. She hung up her white
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: armor in the royal basilica of St. Denis, and went and asked the King
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to relieve her of her functions and let her go home. As usual, she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: wise. Grand combinations, far-reaching great military moves were at an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: end, now; for the future, when the truce should end, the war would be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: merely a war of random and idle skirmishes, apparently; work suitable
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: for subalterns, and not requiring the supervision of a sublime military
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: genius. But the King would not let her go. The truce did not embrace all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: France; there were French strongholds to be watched and preserved; he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would need her. Really, you see, Tremouille wanted to keep her where he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could balk and hinder her.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now came her Voices again. They said, "Remain at St. Denis." There was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: no explanation. They did not say why. That was the voice of God; it took
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: precedence of the command of the King; Joan resolved to stay. But that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: filled La Tremouille with dread. She was too tremendous a force to be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: left to herself; she would surely defeat all his plans. He beguiled the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: King to use compulsion. Joan had to submit--because she was wounded and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: helpless. In the Great Trial she said she was carried away against
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her will; and that if she had not been wounded it could not have been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: accomplished. Ah, she had a spirit, that slender girl! a spirit to brave
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: all earthly powers and defy them. We shall never know why the Voices
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ordered her to stay. We only know this; that if she could have obeyed,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the history of France would not be as it now stands written in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: books. Yes, well we know that.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: On the 13th of September the army, sad and spiritless, turned its
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: face toward the Loire, and marched--without music! Yes, one noted that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: detail. It was a funeral march; that is what it was. A long, dreary
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: funeral march, with never a shout or a cheer; friends looking on in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tears, all the way, enemies laughing. We reached Gien at last--that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: place whence we had set out on our splendid march toward Rheims
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: less than three months before, with flags flying, bands playing, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: victory-flush of Patay glowing in our faces, and the massed multitudes
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: shouting and praising and giving us godspeed. There was a dull rain
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: falling now, the day was dark, the heavens mourned, the spectators were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: few, we had no welcome but the welcome of silence, and pity, and tears.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then the King disbanded that noble army of heroes; it furled its flags,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it stored its arms: the disgrace of France was complete. La Tremouille
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: wore the victor's crown; Joan of Arc, the unconquerable, was conquered.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 41 The Maid Will March No More
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: YES, IT was as I have said: Joan had Paris and France in her grip, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the Hundred Years' War under her heel, and the King made her open her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fist and take away her foot.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now followed about eight months of drifting about with the King and his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: council, and his gay and showy and dancing and flirting and hawking and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: frolicking and serenading and dissipating court--drifting from town to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: town and from castle to castle--a life which was pleasant to us of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: personal staff, but not to Joan. However, she only saw it, she didn't
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: live it. The King did his sincerest best to make her happy, and showed a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: most kind and constant anxiety in this matter.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: All others had to go loaded with the chains of an exacting court
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: etiquette, but she was free, she was privileged. So that she paid
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her duty to the King once a day and passed the pleasant word, nothing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: further was required of her. Naturally, then, she made herself a hermit,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and grieved the weary days through in her own apartments, with her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: thoughts and devotions for company, and the planning of now forever
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: unrealizable military combinations for entertainment. In fancy she moved
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bodies of men from this and that and the other point, so calculating the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: distances to be covered, the time required for each body, and the nature
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the country to be traversed, as to have them appear in sight of each
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: other on a given day or at a given hour and concentrate for battle.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was her only game, her only relief from her burden of sorrow and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: inaction. She played it hour after hour, as others play chess; and lost
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: herself in it, and so got repose for her mind and healing for her heart.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She never complained, of course. It was not her way. She was the sort
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that endure in silence.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But--she was a caged eagle just the same, and pined for the free air and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the alpine heights and the fierce joys of the storm.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: France was full of rovers--disbanded soldiers ready for anything that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: might turn up. Several times, at intervals, when Joan's dull captivity
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: grew too heavy to bear, she was allowed to gather a troop of cavalry and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: make a health-restoring dash against the enemy. These things were a bath
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to her spirits.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was like old times, there at Saint-Pierre-le-Moutier, to see her lead
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: assault after assault, be driven back again and again, but always rally
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and charge anew, all in a blaze of eagerness and delight; till at last
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the tempest of missiles rained so intolerably thick that old D'Aulon,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: who was wounded, sounded the retreat (for the King had charged him on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: his head to let no harm come to Joan); and away everybody rushed after
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: him--as he supposed; but when he turned and looked, there were we of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the staff still hammering away; wherefore he rode back and urged her to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: come, saying she was mad to stay there with only a dozen men. Her eye
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: danced merrily, and she turned upon him crying out:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "A dozen men! name of God, I have fifty-thousand, and will never budge
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: till this place is taken!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Sound the charge!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Which he did, and over the walls we went, and the fortress was ours. Old
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: D'Aulon thought her mind was wandering; but all she meant was, that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she felt the might of fifty thousand men surging in her heart. It was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fanciful expression; but, to my thinking, truer word was never said.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then there was the affair near Lagny, where we charged the intrenched
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Burgundians through the open field four times, the last time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: victoriously; the best prize of it Franquet d'Arras, the free-booter and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pitiless scourge of the region roundabout.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now and then other such affairs; and at last, away toward the end of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: May, 1430, we were in the neighborhood of Compiegne, and Joan resolved
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to go to the help of that place, which was being besieged by the Duke of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Burgundy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I had been wounded lately, and was not able to ride without help; but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the good Dwarf took me on behind him, and I held on to him and was safe
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: enough. We started at midnight, in a sullen downpour of warm rain, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: went slowly and softly and in dead silence, for we had to slip through
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the enemy's lines. We were challenged only once; we made no answer, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: held our breath and crept steadily and stealthily along, and got through
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: without any accident. About three or half past we reached Compiegne,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: just as the gray dawn was breaking in the east.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan set to work at once, and concerted a plan with Guillaume de Flavy,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: captain of the city--a plan for a sortie toward evening against the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: enemy, who was posted in three bodies on the other side of the Oise, in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the level plain. From our side one of the city gates communicated with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a bridge. The end of this bridge was defended on the other side of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: river by one of those fortresses called a boulevard; and this boulevard
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: also commanded a raised road, which stretched from its front across the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: plain to the village of Marguy. A force of Burgundians occupied Marguy;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: another was camped at Clairoix, a couple of miles above the raised road;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and a body of English was holding Venette, a mile and a half below it. A
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: kind of bow-and-arrow arrangement, you see; the causeway the arrow, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: boulevard at the feather-end of it, Marguy at the barb, Venette at one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: end of the bow, Clairoix at the other.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan's plan was to go straight per causeway against Marguy, carry it by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: assault, then turn swiftly upon Clairoix, up to the right, and capture
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that camp in the same way, then face to the rear and be ready for heavy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: work, for the Duke of Burgundy lay behind Clairoix with a reserve.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Flavy's lieutenant, with archers and the artillery of the boulevard,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was to keep the English troops from coming up from below and seizing the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: causeway and cutting off Joan's retreat in case she should have to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: make one. Also, a fleet of covered boats was to be stationed near
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the boulevard as an additional help in case a retreat should become
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: necessary.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was the 24th of May. At four in the afternoon Joan moved out at the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: head of six hundred cavalry--on her last march in this life!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It breaks my heart. I had got myself helped up onto the walls, and from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: there I saw much that happened, the rest was told me long afterward by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: our two knights and other eye-witnesses. Joan crossed the bridge, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: soon left the boulevard behind her and went skimming away over the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: raised road with her horsemen clattering at her heels. She had on a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: brilliant silver-gilt cape over her armor, and I could see it flap and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: flare and rise and fall like a little patch of white flame.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was a bright day, and one could see far and wide over that plain.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Soon we saw the English force advancing, swiftly and in handsome order,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the sunlight flashing from its arms.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan crashed into the Burgundians at Marguy and was repulsed. Then she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: saw the other Burgundians moving down from Clairoix. Joan rallied her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: men and charged again, and was again rolled back. Two assaults occupy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a good deal of time--and time was precious here. The English were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: approaching the road now from Venette, but the boulevard opened fire on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: them and they were checked. Joan heartened her men with inspiring words
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and led them to the charge again in great style. This time she carried
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Marguy with a hurrah. Then she turned at once to the right and plunged
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: into the plan and struck the Clairoix force, which was just arriving;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: then there was heavy work, and plenty of it, the two armies hurling each
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: other backward turn about and about, and victory inclining first to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the one, then to the other. Now all of a sudden there was a panic on our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: side. Some say one thing caused it, some another. Some say the cannonade
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: made our front ranks think retreat was being cut off by the English,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: some say the rear ranks got the idea that Joan was killed. Anyway our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: men broke, and went flying in a wild rout for the causeway. Joan tried
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to rally them and face them around, crying to them that victory was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sure, but it did no good, they divided and swept by her like a wave. Old
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: D'Aulon begged her to retreat while there was yet a chance for safety,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but she refused; so he seized her horse's bridle and bore her along with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the wreck and ruin in spite of herself. And so along the causeway they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: came swarming, that wild confusion of frenzied men and horses--and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: artillery had to stop firing, of course; consequently the English and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Burgundians closed in in safety, the former in front, the latter behind
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: their prey. Clear to the boulevard the French were washed in this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: enveloping inundation; and there, cornered in an angle formed by the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: flank of the boulevard and the slope of the causeway, they bravely
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fought a hopeless fight, and sank down one by one.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Flavy, watching from the city wall, ordered the gate to be closed and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the drawbridge raised. This shut Joan out.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The little personal guard around her thinned swiftly. Both of our good
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: knights went down disabled; Joan's two brothers fell wounded; then Noel
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Rainguesson--all wounded while loyally sheltering Joan from blows aimed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: at her. When only the Dwarf and the Paladin were left, they would not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: give up, but stood their ground stoutly, a pair of steel towers streaked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and splashed with blood; and where the ax of one fell, and the sword of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the other, an enemy gasped and died.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And so fighting, and loyal to their duty to the last, good simple souls,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: they came to their honorable end. Peace to their memories! they were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: very dear to me.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then there was a cheer and a rush, and Joan, still defiant, still laying
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: about her with her sword, was seized by her cape and dragged from her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: horse. She was borne away a prisoner to the Duke of Burgundy's camp, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: after her followed the victorious army roaring its joy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The awful news started instantly on its round; from lip to lip it flew;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and wherever it came it struck the people as with a sort of paralysis;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and they murmured over and over again, as if they were talking to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: themselves, or in their sleep, "The Maid of Orleans taken!... Joan of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Arc a prisoner!... the savior of France lost to us!"--and would keep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: saying that over, as if they couldn't understand how it could be, or how
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: God could permit it, poor creatures!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: You know what a city is like when it is hung from eaves to pavement
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with rustling black? Then you know what Rouse was like, and some other
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: cities. But can any man tell you what the mourning in the hearts of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: peasantry of France was like? No, nobody can tell you that, and,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: poor dumb things, they could not have told you themselves, but it was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: there--indeed, yes. Why, it was the spirit of a whole nation hung with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: crape!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The 24th of May. We will draw down the curtain now upon the most
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: strange, and pathetic, and wonderful military drama that has been played
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon the stage of the world. Joan of Arc will march no more.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: BOOK III TRIAL AND MARTYRDOM
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 1 The Maid in Chains
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I CANNOT bear to dwell at great length upon the shameful history of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the summer and winter following the capture. For a while I was not much
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: troubled, for I was expecting every day to hear that Joan had been put
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to ransom, and that the King--no, not the King, but grateful France--had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: come eagerly forward to pay it. By the laws of war she could not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: be denied the privilege of ransom. She was not a rebel; she was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: legitimately constituted soldier, head of the armies of France by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her King's appointment, and guilty of no crime known to military law;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: therefore she could not be detained upon any pretext, if ransom were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: proffered.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But day after day dragged by and no ransom was offered! It seems
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: incredible, but it is true. Was that reptile Tremouille busy at the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: King's ear? All we know is, that the King was silent, and made no offer
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and no effort in behalf of this poor girl who had done so much for him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But, unhappily, there was alacrity enough in another quarter. The news
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the capture reached Paris the day after it happened, and the glad
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: English and Burgundians deafened the world all the day and all the night
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with the clamor of their joy-bells and the thankful thunder of their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: artillery, and the next day the Vicar-General of the Inquisition sent a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: message to the Duke of Burgundy requiring the delivery of the prisoner
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: into the hands of the Church to be tried as an idolater.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The English had seen their opportunity, and it was the English power
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that was really acting, not the Church. The Church was being used as a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: blind, a disguise; and for a forcible reason: the Church was not only
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: able to take the life of Joan of Arc, but to blight her influence and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the valor-breeding inspiration of her name, whereas the English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: power could but kill her body; that would not diminish or destroy the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: influence of her name; it would magnify it and make it permanent. Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of Arc was the only power in France that the English did not despise,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the only power in France that they considered formidable. If the Church
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could be brought to take her life, or to proclaim her an idolater, a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heretic, a witch, sent from Satan, not from heaven, it was believed that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the English supremacy could be at once reinstated.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Duke of Burgundy listened--but waited. He could not doubt that the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: French King or the French people would come forward presently and pay a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: higher price than the English. He kept Joan a close prisoner in a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong fortress, and continued to wait, week after week. He was a French
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: prince, and was at heart ashamed to sell her to the English. Yet with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: all his waiting no offer came to him from the French side.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: One day Joan played a cunning trick on her jailer, and not only slipped
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: out of her prison, but locked him up in it. But as she fled away she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: seen by a sentinel, and was caught and brought back.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then she was sent to Beaurevoir, a stronger castle. This was early in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: August, and she had been in captivity more than two months now. Here she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was shut up in the top of a tower which was sixty feet high. She ate her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heart there for another long stretch--about three months and a half.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And she was aware, all these weary five months of captivity, that the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: English, under cover of the Church, were dickering for her as one would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dicker for a horse or a slave, and that France was silent, the King
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: silent, all her friends the same. Yes, it was pitiful.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And yet when she heard at last that Compiegne was being closely besieged
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and likely to be captured, and that the enemy had declared that no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: inhabitant of it should escape massacre, not even children of seven
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: years of age, she was in a fever at once to fly to our rescue. So she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tore her bedclothes to strips and tied them together and descended
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: this frail rope in the night, and it broke, and she fell and was badly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bruised, and remained three days insensible, meantime neither eating nor
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: drinking.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And now came relief to us, led by the Count of Vendome, and Compiegne
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was saved and the siege raised. This was a disaster to the Duke of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Burgundy. He had to save money now. It was a good time for a new bid to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: be made for Joan of Arc. The English at once sent a French bishop--that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: forever infamous Pierre Cauchon of Beauvais. He was partly promised
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the Archbishopric of Rouen, which was vacant, if he should succeed. He
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: claimed the right to preside over Joan's ecclesiastical trial because
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the battle-ground where she was taken was within his diocese. By the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: military usage of the time the ransom of a royal prince was 10,000
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: livres of gold, which is 61,125 francs--a fixed sum, you see. It must be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: accepted when offered; it could not be refused.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon brought the offer of this very sum from the English--a royal
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: prince's ransom for the poor little peasant-girl of Domremy. It shows
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in a striking way the English idea of her formidable importance. It was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: accepted. For that sum Joan of Arc, the Savior of France, was sold; sold
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to her enemies; to the enemies of her country; enemies who had lashed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and thrashed and thumped and trounced France for a century and made
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: holiday sport of it; enemies who had forgotten, years and years ago,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: what a Frenchman's face was like, so used were they to seeing nothing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but his back; enemies whom she had whipped, whom she had cowed, whom she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had taught to respect French valor, new-born in her nation by the breath
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of her spirit; enemies who hungered for her life as being the only
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: puissance able to stand between English triumph and French degradation.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Sold to a French priest by a French prince, with the French King and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: French nation standing thankless by and saying nothing.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And she--what did she say? Nothing. Not a reproach passed her lips. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was too great for that--she was Joan of Arc; and when that is said, all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: is said.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: As a soldier, her record was spotless. She could not be called to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: account for anything under that head. A subterfuge must be found, and,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: as we have seen, was found. She must be tried by priests for crimes
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: against religion. If none could be discovered, some must be invented.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Let the miscreant Cauchon alone to contrive those.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Rouen was chosen as the scene of the trial. It was in the heart of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: English power; its population had been under English dominion so many
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: generations that they were hardly French now, save in language. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: place was strongly garrisoned. Joan was taken there near the end of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: December, 1430, and flung into a dungeon. Yes, and clothed in chains,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that free spirit!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Still France made no move. How do I account for this? I think there is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: only one way. You will remember that whenever Joan was not at the front,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the French held back and ventured nothing; that whenever she led, they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: swept everything before them, so long as they could see her white
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: armor or her banner; that every time she fell wounded or was reported
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: killed--as at Compiegne--they broke in panic and fled like sheep. I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: argue from this that they had undergone no real transformation as yet;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that at bottom they were still under the spell of a timorousness born of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: generations of unsuccess, and a lack of confidence in each other and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in their leaders born of old and bitter experience in the way of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: treacheries of all sorts--for their kings had been treacherous to their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: great vassals and to their generals, and these in turn were treacherous
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to the head of the state and to each other. The soldiery found that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: they could depend utterly on Joan, and upon her alone. With her gone,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: everything was gone. She was the sun that melted the frozen torrents and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: set them boiling; with that sun removed, they froze again, and the army
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and all France became what they had been before, mere dead corpses--that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and nothing more; incapable of thought, hope, ambition, or motion.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark
