author: Twain, Mark

text: MY WOUND gave me a great deal of trouble clear into the first part of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: October; then the fresher weather renewed my life and strength. All this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: time there were reports drifting about that the King was going to ransom
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan. I believed these, for I was young and had not yet found out the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: littleness and meanness of our poor human race, which brags about itself
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: so much, and thinks it is better and higher than the other animals.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: In October I was well enough to go out with two sorties, and in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: second one, on the 23d, I was wounded again. My luck had turned,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: you see. On the night of the 25th the besiegers decamped, and in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: disorder and confusion one of their prisoners escaped and got safe into
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Compiegne, and hobbled into my room as pallid and pathetic an object as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: you would wish to see.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What? Alive? Noel Rainguesson!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was indeed he. It was a most joyful meeting, that you will easily
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: know; and also as sad as it was joyful. We could not speak Joan's name.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: One's voice would have broken down. We knew who was meant when she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mentioned; we could say "she" and "her," but we could not speak the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: name.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We talked of the personal staff. Old D'Aulon, wounded and a prisoner,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was still with Joan and serving her, by permission of the Duke of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Burgundy. Joan was being treated with respect due to her rank and to her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: character as a prisoner of war taken in honorable conflict. And this was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: continued--as we learned later--until she fell into the hands of that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bastard of Satan, Pierre Cauchon, Bishop of Beauvais.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Noel was full of noble and affectionate praises and appreciations of our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: old boastful big Standard-Bearer, now gone silent forever, his real and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: imaginary battles all fought, his work done, his life honorably closed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and completed.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And think of his luck!" burst out Noel, with his eyes full of tears.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Always the pet child of luck!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "See how it followed him and stayed by him, from his first step all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: through, in the field or out of it; always a splendid figure in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: public eye, courted and envied everywhere; always having a chance to do
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fine things and always doing them; in the beginning called the Paladin
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in joke, and called it afterward in earnest because he magnificently
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: made the title good; and at last--supremest luck of all--died in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the field! died with his harness on; died faithful to his charge, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Standard in his hand; died--oh, think of it--with the approving eye of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan of Arc upon him!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "He drained the cup of glory to the last drop, and went jubilant to his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: peace, blessedly spared all part in the disaster which was to follow.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: What luck, what luck! And we? What was our sin that we are still here,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: we who have also earned our place with the happy dead?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And presently he said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "They tore the sacred Standard from his dead hand and carried it away,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: their most precious prize after its captured owner. But they haven't it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: now. A month ago we put our lives upon the risk--our two good knights,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: my fellow-prisoners, and I--and stole it, and got it smuggled by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: trusty hands to Orleans, and there it is now, safe for all time in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Treasury."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was glad and grateful to learn that. I have seen it often since, when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I have gone to Orleans on the 8th of May to be the petted old guest of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the city and hold the first place of honor at the banquets and in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: processions--I mean since Joan's brothers passed from this life. It will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: still be there, sacredly guarded by French love, a thousand years from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: now--yes, as long as any shred of it hangs together. (1) Two or three
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: weeks after this talk came the tremendous news like a thunder-clap, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: we were aghast--Joan of Arc sold to the English!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Not for a moment had we ever dreamed of such a thing. We were young, you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: see, and did not know the human race, as I have said before. We had been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: so proud of our country, so sure of her nobleness, her magnanimity,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her gratitude. We had expected little of the King, but of France we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had expected everything. Everybody knew that in various towns patriot
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: priests had been marching in procession urging the people to sacrifice
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: money, property, everything, and buy the freedom of their heaven-sent
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: deliverer. That the money would be raised we had not thought of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: doubting.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But it was all over now, all over. It was a bitter time for us. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heavens seemed hung with black; all cheer went out from our hearts.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Was this comrade here at my bedside really Noel Rainguesson, that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: light-hearted creature whose whole life was but one long joke, and who
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: used up more breath in laughter than in keeping his body alive? No, no;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that Noel I was to see no more. This one's heart was broken. He moved
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: grieving about, and absently, like one in a dream; the stream of his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: laughter was dried at its source.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Well, that was best. It was my own mood. We were company for each other.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: He nursed me patiently through the dull long weeks, and at last, in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: January, I was strong enough to go about again. Then he said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Shall we go now?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was no need to explain. Our hearts were in Rouen; we would carry
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: our bodies there. All that we cared for in this life was shut up in that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fortress. We could not help her, but it would be some solace to us to be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: near her, to breathe the air that she breathed, and look daily upon the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stone walls that hid her. What if we should be made prisoners there?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Well, we could but do our best, and let luck and fate decide what should
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: happen.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And so we started. We could not realize the change which had come upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the country. We seemed able to choose our own route and go whenever we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pleased, unchallenged and unmolested. When Joan of Arc was in the field
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: there was a sort of panic of fear everywhere; but now that she was out
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the way, fear had vanished. Nobody was troubled about you or afraid
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of you, nobody was curious about you or your business, everybody was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: indifferent.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We presently saw that we could take to the Seine, and not weary
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ourselves out with land travel.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: So we did it, and were carried in a boat to within a league of Rouen.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then we got ashore; not on the hilly side, but on the other, where it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: is as level as a floor. Nobody could enter or leave the city without
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: explaining himself. It was because they feared attempts at a rescue of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We had no trouble. We stopped in the plain with a family of peasants and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stayed a week, helping them with their work for board and lodging, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: making friends of them. We got clothes like theirs, and wore them.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: When we had worked our way through their reserves and gotten their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: confidence, we found that they secretly harbored French hearts in their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bodies. Then we came out frankly and told them everything, and found
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: them ready to do anything they could to help us.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Our plan was soon made, and was quite simple. It was to help them drive
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a flock of sheep to the market of the city. One morning early we made
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the venture in a melancholy drizzle of rain, and passed through the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that run down from the cathedral to the river, and with these they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bestowed us; and the next day they smuggled our own proper clothing and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: several suits of state apparel, and other relics of the Maid, by a mob

author: Twain, Mark

text: in the time of the Revolution. Nothing which the hand of Joan of Arc is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: known to have touched now remains in existence except a few preciously
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: guarded military and state papers which she signed, her pen being guided
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: by a clerk or her secretary, Louis de Conte. A boulder exists from which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she is known to have mounted her horse when she was once setting out
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon a campaign. Up to a quarter of a century ago there was a single
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hair from her head still in existence. It was drawn through the wax of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a seal attached to the parchment of a state document. It was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: surreptitiously snipped out, seal and all, by some vandal relic-hunter,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and carried off. Doubtless it still exists, but only the thief knows
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: where. -- TRANSLATOR.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 3 Weaving the Net About Her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: IT WAS necessary for me to have some way to gain bread for Noel and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: myself; and when the Pierrons found that I knew how to write, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: applied to their confessor in my behalf, and he got a place for me with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a good priest named Manchon, who was to be the chief recorder in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Great Trial of Joan of Arc now approaching. It was a strange position
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: for me--clerk to the recorder--and dangerous if my sympathies and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: late employment should be found out. But there was not much danger.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Manchon was at bottom friendly to Joan and would not betray me; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: my name would not, for I had discarded my surname and retained only my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: given one, like a person of low degree.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I attended Manchon constantly straight along, out of January and into
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: February, and was often in the citadel with him--in the very fortress
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: where Joan was imprisoned, though not in the dungeon where she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: confined, and so did not see her, of course.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Manchon told me everything that had been happening before my coming.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Ever since the purchase of Joan, Cauchon had been busy packing his jury
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: for the destruction of the Maid--weeks and weeks he had spent in this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bad industry. The University of Paris had sent him a number of learned
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and able and trusty ecclesiastics of the stripe he wanted; and he had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: scraped together a clergyman of like stripe and great fame here and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: there and yonder, until he was able to construct a formidable court
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: numbering half a hundred distinguished names. French names they were,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but their interests and sympathies were English.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: A great officer of the Inquisition was also sent from Paris for the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: accused must be tried by the forms of the Inquisition; but this was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: brave and righteous man, and he said squarely that this court had no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: power to try the case, wherefore he refused to act; and the same honest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: talk was uttered by two or three others.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Inquisitor was right. The case as here resurrected against Joan had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: already been tried long ago at Poitiers, and decided in her favor. Yes,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and by a higher tribunal than this one, for at the head of it was an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Archbishop--he of Rheims--Cauchon's own metropolitan. So here, you see,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a lower court was impudently preparing to try and redecide a cause which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had already been decided by its superior, a court of higher authority.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Imagine it! No, the case could not properly be tried again. Cauchon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could not properly preside in this new court, for more than one reason:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Rouen was not in his diocese; Joan had not been arrested in her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: domicile, which was still Domremy; and finally this proposed judge was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the prisoner's outspoken enemy, and therefore he was incompetent to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: try her. Yet all these large difficulties were gotten rid of. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: territorial Chapter of Rouen finally granted territorial letters to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon--though only after a struggle and under compulsion. Force was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: also applied to the Inquisitor, and he was obliged to submit.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: So then, the little English King, by his representative, formally
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: delivered Joan into the hands of the court, but with this reservation:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: if the court failed to condemn her, he was to have her back again! Ah,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dear, what chance was there for that forsaken and friendless child?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Friendless, indeed--it is the right word. For she was in a black
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dungeon, with half a dozen brutal common soldiers keeping guard night
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and day in the room where her cage was--for she was in a cage; an iron
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: cage, and chained to her bed by neck and hands and feet. Never a person
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: near her whom she had ever seen before; never a woman at all. Yes, this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was, indeed, friendlessness.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now it was a vassal of Jean de Luxembourg who captured Joan and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Compiegne, and it was Jean who sold her to the Duke of Burgundy. Yet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: this very De Luxembourg was shameless enough to go and show his face to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan in her cage. He came with two English earls, Warwick and Stafford.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: He was a poor reptile. He told her he would get her set free if she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would promise not to fight the English any more. She had been in that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: cage a long time now, but not long enough to break her spirit. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: retorted scornfully:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Name of God, you but mock me. I know that you have neither the power
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: nor the will to do it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: He insisted. Then the pride and dignity of the soldier rose in Joan, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she lifted her chained hands and let them fall with a clash, saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "See these! They know more than you, and can prophesy better. I know that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the English are going to kill me, for they think that when I am dead
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: they can get the Kingdom of France. It is not so.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Though there were a hundred thousand of them they would never get it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: This defiance infuriated Stafford, and he--now think of it--he a free,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong man, she a chained and helpless girl--he drew his dagger and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: flung himself at her to stab her. But Warwick seized him and held him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: back. Warwick was wise. Take her life in that way? Send her to Heaven
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stainless and undisgraced? It would make her the idol of France, and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: whole nation would rise and march to victory and emancipation under the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: inspiration of her spirit. No, she must be saved for another fate than
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Well, the time was approaching for the Great Trial. For more than two
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: months Cauchon had been raking and scraping everywhere for any odds and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ends of evidence or suspicion or conjecture that might be usable against
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan, and carefully suppressing all evidence that came to hand in her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: favor. He had limitless ways and means and powers at his disposal for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: preparing and strengthening the case for the prosecution, and he used
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: them all.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But Joan had no one to prepare her case for her, and she was shut up in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: those stone walls and had no friend to appeal to for help. And as for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: witnesses, she could not call a single one in her defense; they were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: all far away, under the French flag, and this was an English court; they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would have been seized and hanged if they had shown their faces at the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: gates of Rouen. No, the prisoner must be the sole witness--witness for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the prosecution, witness for the defense; and with a verdict of death
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: resolved upon before the doors were opened for the court's first
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sitting.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: When she learned that the court was made up of ecclesiastics in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: interest of the English, she begged that in fairness an equal number of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: priests of the French party should be added to these.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon scoffed at her message, and would not even deign to answer it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: By the law of the Church--she being a minor under twenty-one--it was her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: right to have counsel to conduct her case, advise her how to answer
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: when questioned, and protect her from falling into traps set by cunning
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: devices of the prosecution. She probably did not know that this was her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: right, and that she could demand it and require it, for there was none
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to tell her that; but she begged for this help, at any rate. Cauchon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: refused it. She urged and implored, pleading her youth and her ignorance
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the complexities and intricacies of the law and of legal procedure.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon refused again, and said she must get along with her case as best
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she might by herself. Ah, his heart was a stone.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon prepared the proces verbal. I will simplify that by calling it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the Bill of Particulars. It was a detailed list of the charges against
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her, and formed the basis of the trial. Charges? It was a list of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: suspicions and public rumors--those were the words used. It was merely
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: charged that she was suspected of having been guilty of heresies,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: witchcraft, and other such offenses against religion.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now by the law of the Church, a trial of that sort could not be begun
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: until a searching inquiry had been made into the history and character
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the accused, and it was essential that the result of this inquiry be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: added to the proces verbal and form a part of it. You remember that that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was the first thing they did before the trial at Poitiers. They did it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: again now. An ecclesiastic was sent to Domremy. There and all about
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the neighborhood he made an exhaustive search into Joan's history
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and character, and came back with his verdict. It was very clear. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: searcher reported that he found Joan's character to be in every way what
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: he "would like his own sister's character to be." Just about the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: same report that was brought back to Poitiers, you see. Joan's was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: character which could endure the minutest examination.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: This verdict was a strong point for Joan, you will say. Yes, it would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: have been if it could have seen the light; but Cauchon was awake, and it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: disappeared from the proces verbal before the trial. People were prudent
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: enough not to inquire what became of it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: One would imagine that Cauchon was ready to begin the trial by this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: time. But no, he devised one more scheme for poor Joan's destruction,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and it promised to be a deadly one.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: One of the great personages picked out and sent down by the University
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of Paris was an ecclesiastic named Nicolas Loyseleur. He was tall,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: handsome, grave, of smooth, soft speech and courteous and winning
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: manners. There was no seeming of treachery or hypocrisy about him,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: yet he was full of both. He was admitted to Joan's prison by night,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: disguised as a cobbler; he pretended to be from her own country; he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: professed to be secretly a patriot; he revealed the fact that he was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a priest. She was filled with gladness to see one from the hills and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: plains that were so dear to her; happier still to look upon a priest and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: disburden her heart in confession, for the offices of the Church were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the bread of life, the breath of her nostrils to her, and she had been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: long forced to pine for them in vain. She opened her whole innocent
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heart to this creature, and in return he gave her advice concerning her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: trial which could have destroyed her if her deep native wisdom had not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: protected her against following it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: You will ask, what value could this scheme have, since the secrets of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the confessional are sacred and cannot be revealed? True--but suppose
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: another person should overhear them? That person is not bound to keep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the secret. Well, that is what happened. Cauchon had previously caused
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a hole to be bored through the wall; and he stood with his ear to that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hole and heard all. It is pitiful to think of these things. One wonders
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: how they could treat that poor child so. She had not done them any harm.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 4 All Ready to Condemn
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ON TUESDAY, the 20th of February, while I sat at my master's work in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: evening, he came in, looking sad, and said it had been decided to begin
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the trial at eight o'clock the next morning, and I must get ready to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: assist him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Of course I had been expecting such news every day for many days; but no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: matter, the shock of it almost took my breath away and set me trembling
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: like a leaf. I suppose that without knowing it I had been half imagining
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that at the last moment something would happen, something that would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stop this fatal trial; maybe that La Hire would burst in at the gates
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with his hellions at his back; maybe that God would have pity and

text: It was the soldier in him responding to the soldier in her. But what

author: Twain, Mark

text: a stinging rebuke it was, what an arraignment of French character and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: city, would have risen to the last man and the last woman, and marched
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: upon Rouen. Some speeches--speeches that shame a man and humble
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: him--burn themselves into the memory and remain there. That one is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: burned into mine.

author: Twain, Mark

text: After Joan had made oath, Cauchon asked her her name, and where she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: born, and some questions about her family; also what her age was. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: answered these. Then he asked her how much education she had.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I have learned from my mother the Pater Noster, the Ave Maria, and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Belief. All that I know was taught me by my mother."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Questions of this unessential sort dribbled on for a considerable time.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Everybody was tired out by now, except Joan. The tribunal prepared to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: rise. At this point Cauchon forbade Joan to try to escape from prison,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon pain of being held guilty of the crime of heresy--singular logic!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She answered simply:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I am not bound by this proposition. If I could escape I would not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: reproach myself, for I have given no promise, and I shall not."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then she complained of the burden of her chains, and asked that they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: might be removed, for she was strongly guarded in that dungeon and there
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was no need of them. But the Bishop refused, and reminded her that she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had broken out of prison twice before. Joan of Arc was too proud to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: insist. She only said, as she rose to go with the guard:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is true, I have wanted to escape, and I do want to escape." Then she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: added, in a way that would touch the pity of anybody, I think, "It is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the right of every prisoner."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And so she went from the place in the midst of an impressive stillness,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: which made the sharper and more distressful to me the clank of those
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pathetic chains.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: What presence of mind she had! One could never surprise her out of it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She saw Noel and me there when she first took her seat on the bench,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and we flushed to the forehead with excitement and emotion, but her face
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: showed nothing, betrayed nothing. Her eyes sought us fifty times that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: day, but they passed on and there was never any ray of recognition in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: them. Another would have started upon seeing us, and then--why, then
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: there could have been trouble for us, of course.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: THAT NIGHT Manchon told me that all through the day's proceedings
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon had had some clerks concealed in the embrasure of a window who
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: were to make a special report garbling Joan's answers and twisting them
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: from their right meaning. Ah, that was surely the cruelest man and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: most shameless that has lived in this world. But his scheme failed.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Those clerks had human hearts in them, and their base work revolted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: them, and they turned to and boldly made a straight report, whereupon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon cursed them and ordered them out of his presence with a threat
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of drowning, which was his favorite and most frequent menace. The matter
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had gotten abroad and was making great and unpleasant talk, and Cauchon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would not try to repeat this shabby game right away. It comforted me to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hear that.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: When we arrived at the citadel next morning, we found that a change
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had been made. The chapel had been found too small. The court had now
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: removed to a noble chamber situated at the end of the great hall of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: castle. The number of judges was increased to sixty-two--one ignorant
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: girl against such odds, and none to help her.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The prisoner was brought in. She was as white as ever, but she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: looking no whit worse than she looked when she had first appeared the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: day before. Isn't it a strange thing? Yesterday she had sat five hours
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: on that backless bench with her chains in her lap, baited, badgered,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: persecuted by that unholy crew, without even the refreshment of a cup of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: water--for she was never offered anything, and if I have made you know
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her by this time you will know without my telling you that she was not a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: person likely to ask favors of those people. And she had spent the night
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: caged in her wintry dungeon with her chains upon her; yet here she was,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: as I say, collected, unworn, and ready for the conflict; yes, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the only person there who showed no signs of the wear and worry of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: yesterday. And her eyes--ah, you should have seen them and broken your
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hearts. Have you seen that veiled deep glow, that pathetic hurt dignity,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that unsubdued and unsubduable spirit that burns and smolders in the eye
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of a caged eagle and makes you feel mean and shabby under the burden of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: its mute reproach? Her eyes were like that. How capable they were, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: how wonderful! Yes, at all times and in all circumstances they could
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: express as by print every shade of the wide range of her moods. In
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: them were hidden floods of gay sunshine, the softest and peacefulest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: twilights, and devastating storms and lightnings. Not in this world have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: there been others that were comparable to them. Such is my opinion, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: none that had the privilege to see them would say otherwise than this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: which I have said concerning them.

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: truly answer the questions which I am going to ask you, as you have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: questions.

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: services of the Church. And it told me that I must go to France."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "In what species of form did the Voice appear?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan looked suspiciously at he priest a moment, then said, tranquilly:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "As to that, I will not tell you."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Did the Voice seek you often?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes. Twice or three times a week, saying, 'Leave your village and go to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: France.'"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Did you father know about your departure?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No. The Voice said, 'Go to France'; therefore I could not abide at home
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: any longer."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What else did it say?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "That I should raise the siege of Orleans."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Was that all?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No, I was to go to Vaucouleurs, and Robert de Baudricourt would give
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: me soldiers to go with me to France; and I answered, saying that I was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: poor girl who did not know how to ride, neither how to fight."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then she told how she was balked and interrupted at Vaucouleurs, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: finally got her soldiers, and began her march.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "How were you dressed?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The court of Poitiers had distinctly decided and decreed that as God had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: appointed her to do a man's work, it was meet and no scandal to religion
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that she should dress as a man; but no matter, this court was ready to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: use any and all weapons against Joan, even broken and discredited ones,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and much was going to be made of this one before this trial should end.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I wore a man's dress, also a sword which Robert de Baudricourt gave me,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but no other weapon."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan was suspicious again. She would not answer.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The question was repeated.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to me he said, 'Go, and let happen what may!'" (Advienne que pourra!)
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: After a good deal of questioning upon other matters she was asked again
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I believe my Voice gave me good advice."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was all that could be got out of her, so the questions wandered to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: other matters, and finally to her first meeting with the King at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Finally:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Do you still hear those Voices?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "They come to me every day."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What do you ask of them?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I have never asked of them any recompense but the salvation of my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: soul."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: He is creeping upon her again. She answered:

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had been free, but I was helpless by my wound, and the knights carried
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: me away by force."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "When were you wounded?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I was wounded in the moat before Paris, in the assault."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The next question reveals what Beaupere had been leading up to:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Was it a feast-day?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: You see? The suggestion that a voice coming from God would hardly advise
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: or permit the violation, by war and bloodshed, of a sacred day.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan was troubled a moment, then she answered yes, it was a feast-day.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now, then, tell the this: did you hold it right to make the attack on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: such a day?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: This was a shot which might make the first breach in a wall which had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: suffered no damage thus far. There was immediate silence in the court
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and intense expectancy noticeable all about. But Joan disappointed the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: house. She merely made a slight little motion with her hand, as when one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: brushes away a fly, and said with reposeful indifference:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark
