text: "Passez outre."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Smiles danced for a moment in some of the sternest faces there,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and several men even laughed outright. The trap had been long and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: laboriously prepared; it fell, and was empty.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The court rose. It had sat for hours, and was cruelly fatigued. Most
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the time had been taken up with apparently idle and purposeless
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: inquiries about the Chinon events, the exiled Duke of Orleans, Joan's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: first proclamation, and so on, but all this seemingly random stuff
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had really been sown thick with hidden traps. But Joan had fortunately
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: escaped them all, some by the protecting luck which attends upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ignorance and innocence, some by happy accident, the others by force of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her best and surest helper, the clear vision and lightning intuitions of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her extraordinary mind.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now, then, this daily baiting and badgering of this friendless girl, a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: captive in chains, was to continue a long, long time--dignified sport,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a kennel of mastiffs and bloodhounds harassing a kitten!--and I may as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: well tell you, upon sworn testimony, what it was like from the first
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: day to the last. When poor Joan had been in her grave a quarter of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a century, the Pope called together that great court which was to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: re-examine her history, and whose just verdict cleared her illustrious
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: name from every spot and stain, and laid upon the verdict and conduct
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of our Rouen tribunal the blight of its everlasting execrations. Manchon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and several of the judges who had been members of our court were among
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the witnesses who appeared before that Tribunal of Rehabilitation.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Recalling these miserable proceedings which I have been telling you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: about, Manchon testified thus:--here you have it, all in fair print in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the unofficial history:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: When Joan spoke of her apparitions she was interrupted at almost every
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: word. They wearied her with long and multiplied interrogatories upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: all sorts of things. Almost every day the interrogatories of the morning
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: lasted three or four hours; then from these morning interrogatories they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: extracted the particularly difficult and subtle points, and these served
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: as material for the afternoon interrogatories, which lasted two or three
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hours. Moment by moment they skipped from one subject to another; yet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in spite of this she always responded with an astonishing wisdom and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: memory. She often corrected the judges, saying, "But I have already
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: answered that once before--ask the recorder," referring them to me.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And here is the testimony of one of Joan's judges. Remember, these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: witnesses are not talking about two or three days, they are talking
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: about a tedious long procession of days:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: They asked her profound questions, but she extricated herself quite
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: well. Sometimes the questioners changed suddenly and passed on to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: another subject to see if she would not contradict herself. They
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: burdened her with long interrogatories of two or three hours, from which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the judges themselves went forth fatigued. From the snares with which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she was beset the expertest man in the world could not have extricated
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: himself but with difficulty. She gave her responses with great prudence;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: indeed to such a degree that during three weeks I believed she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: inspired.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Ah, had she a mind such as I have described? You see what these priests
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: say under oath--picked men, men chosen for their places in that terrible
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: court on account of their learning, their experience, their keen and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: practised intellects, and their strong bias against the prisoner. They
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: make that poor country-girl out the match, and more than the match, of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the sixty-two trained adepts. Isn't it so? They from the University of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Paris, she from the sheepfold and the cow-stable!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Ah, yes, she was great, she was wonderful. It took six thousand years
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to produce her; her like will not be seen in the earth again in fifty
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: thousand. Such is my opinion.

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: day, 24th of February.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ended, the robed sixty-two massed in their chairs and the guards and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tell the truth concerning everything asked her!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan's eyes kindled, and she rose; rose and stood, fine and noble, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: faced toward the Bishop and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: terrible responsibility on yourself and you presume too far."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: threat--the threat of instant condemnation unless she obeyed. That
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: blanch--for it meant fire and the stake! But Joan, still standing,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: answered him back, proud and undismayed:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: right!"

author: Twain, Mark

text: spectators. Joan resumed her seat.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

text: she knew--but not all that she knew."

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: tone:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

text: There was no answer. It was a subject that had to be got around and put
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: aside. That book had wisely been gotten out of the way, for it contained

author: Twain, Mark

text: things which would be very awkward here.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: against her.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: desire?"

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "But in this particular case do you think you did well in taking the

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: him from Paris or somewhere where I could be at rest."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: The matter was dropped. They produced and read a copy of Joan's first

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: from the siege of Orleans and vacate France--truly a great and fine
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: production for an unpractised girl of seventeen.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Do you acknowledge as your own the document which has just been read?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, except that there are errors in it--words which make me give
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: did not call myself 'Commander-in-Chief' (chef de guerre). All those are
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: words which my secretary substituted; or mayhap he misheard me or forgot
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: what I said."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She did not look at me when she said it: she spared me that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: embarrassment. I hadn't misheard her at all, and hadn't forgotten.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: entitled to call herself so, and it was becoming and proper, too; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a cipher? If any surrendering was done, it would be to the noble Maid of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Vaucouleurs, already famed and formidable though she had not yet struck
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a blow.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Ah, there would have been a fine and disagreeable episode (for me)
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not only present, but helping build the record; and not only that, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: destined at a far distant day to testify against lies and perversions
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: smuggled into it by Cauchon and deliver them over to eternal infamy!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I do."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Have you repented of it? Do you retract it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Ah, then she was indignant!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No! Not even these chains"--and she shook them--"not even these chains
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: can chill the hopes that I uttered there. And more!"--she rose, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stood a moment with a divine strange light kindling in her face, then
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her words burst forth as in a flood--"I warn you now that before seven
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: years a disaster will smite the English, oh, many fold greater than the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fall of Orleans! and--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Silence! Sit down!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "--and then, soon after, they will lose all France!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now consider these things. The French armies no longer existed. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: French cause was standing still, our King was standing still, there was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: no hint that by and by the Constable Richemont would come forward and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: take up the great work of Joan of Arc and finish it. In face of all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: this, Joan made that prophecy--made it with perfect confidence--and it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: came true. For within five years Paris fell--1436--and our King marched
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: into it flying the victor's flag. So the first part of the prophecy was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: then fulfilled--in fact, almost the entire prophecy; for, with Paris in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: our hands, the fulfilment of the rest of it was assured.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Twenty years later all France was ours excepting a single town--Calais.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now that will remind you of an earlier prophecy of Joan's. At the time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that she wanted to take Paris and could have done it with ease if our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: King had but consented, she said that that was the golden time; that,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with Paris ours, all France would be ours in six months. But if this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: golden opportunity to recover France was wasted, said she, "I give you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: twenty years to do it in."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was right. After Paris fell, in 1436, the rest of the work had to be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: done city by city, castle by castle, and it took twenty years to finish
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, it was the first day of March, 1431, there in the court, that she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stood in the view of everybody and uttered that strange and incredible
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: prediction. Now and then, in this world, somebody's prophecy turns
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: up correct, but when you come to look into it there is sure to be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: considerable room for suspicion that the prophecy was made after the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fact. But here the matter is different. There in that court Joan's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: prophecy was set down in the official record at the hour and moment of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: its utterance, years before the fulfilment, and there you may read it to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: this day.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Twenty-five years after Joan's death the record was produced in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: great Court of the Rehabilitation and verified under oath by Manchon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and me, and surviving judges of our court confirmed the exactness of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: record in their testimony.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan' startling utterance on that now so celebrated first of March
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stirred up a great turmoil, and it was some time before it quieted down
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: again. Naturally, everybody was troubled, for a prophecy is a grisly and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heaven.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: All that these people felt sure of was, that the inspiration back of it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was genuine and puissant.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: They would have given their right hands to know the source of it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: At last the questions began again.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: here before me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: This sort of answer was not going to allay the spreading uneasiness.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: Saints and angels who did not condescend to speak English is a grave

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: You have one of them. It is the gift of my brother. Give it back to me.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: The judges conceived the idea that maybe these rings were for the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: working of enchantments.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Perhaps they could be made to do Joan a damage.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Where is the other ring?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The Burgundians have it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Where did you get it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "My father and mother gave it to me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Describe it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is plain and simple and has 'Jesus and Mary' engraved upon it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Everybody could see that that was not a valuable equipment to do devil's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: work with. So that trail was not worth following. Still, to make sure,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: touching them with the ring. She said no.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tree?"

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: Do you remember Loyseleur, the hypocrite, the treacherous priest,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tool of Cauchon? Do you remember that under the sacred seal of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: confessional Joan freely and trustingly revealed to him everything
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: concerning her history save only a few things regarding her supernatural
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: revelations which her Voices had forbidden her to tell to any one--and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that the unjust judge, Cauchon, was a hidden listener all the time?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now you understand how the inquisitors were able to devise that long
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: array of minutely prying questions; questions whose subtlety and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ingenuity and penetration are astonishing until we come to remember
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Loyseleur's performance and recognize their source. Ah, Bishop of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Beauvais, you are now lamenting this cruel iniquity these many years
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in hell! Yes verily, unless one has come to your help. There is but one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: among the redeemed that would do it; and it is futile to hope that that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: one has not already done it--Joan of Arc.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We will return to the questionings.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Did they make you still another promise?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, but that is not in your proces. I will not tell it now, but before
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: three months I will tell it you."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The judge seems to know the matter he is asking about, already; one gets
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: this idea from his next question.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Did your Voices tell you that you would be liberated before three
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: months?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan often showed a little flash of surprise at the good guessing of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: judges, and she showed one this time. I was frequently in terror to find
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: my mind (which I could not control) criticizing the Voices and saying,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "They counsel her to speak boldly--a thing which she would do without
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: any suggestion from them or anybody else--but when it comes to telling
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her any useful thing, such as how these conspirators manage to guess
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: their way so skilfully into her affairs, they are always off attending
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to some other business."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I am reverent by nature; and when such thoughts swept through my head
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: they made me cold with fear, and if there was a storm and thunder at the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: time, I was so ill that I could but with difficulty abide at my post and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: do my work.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan answered:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "That is not in your proces. I do not know when I shall be set free, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: some who wish me out of this world will go from it before me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It made some of them shiver.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Have your Voices told you that you will be delivered from this prison?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Without a doubt they had, and the judge knew it before he asked the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: question.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ask me again in three months and I will tell you." She said it with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: such a happy look, the tired prisoner! And I? And Noel Rainguesson,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: drooping yonder?--why, the floods of joy went streaming through us from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: crown to sole! It was all that we could do to hold still and keep from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: making fatal exposure of our feelings.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was to be set free in three months. That was what she meant; we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: saw it. The Voices had told her so, and told her true--true to the very
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: day--May 30th. But we know now that they had mercifully hidden from her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: how she was to be set free, but left her in ignorance. Home again!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: That day was our understanding of it--Noel's and mine; that was our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dream; and now we would count the days, the hours, the minutes. They
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would fly lightly along; they would soon be over.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, we would carry our idol home; and there, far from the pomps and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tumults of the world, we would take up our happy life again and live
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it out as we had begun it, in the free air and the sunshine, with the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: friendly sheep and the friendly people for comrades, and the grace and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: charm of the meadows, the woods, and the river always before our eyes
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and their deep peace in our hearts. Yes, that was our dream, the dream
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that carried us bravely through that three months to an exact and awful
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fulfilment, the thought of which would have killed us, I think, if we had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: foreknown it and been obliged to bear the burden of it upon our hearts
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the half of those weary days.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Our reading of the prophecy was this: We believed the King's soul was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: going to be smitten with remorse; and that he would privately plan a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: rescue with Joan's old lieutenants, D'Alencon and the Bastard and La
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Hire, and that this rescue would take place at the end of the three
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: months. So we made up our minds to be ready and take a hand in it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: In the present and also in later sittings Joan was urged to name the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: exact day of her deliverance; but she could not do that. She had not the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: permission of her Voices. Moreover, the Voices themselves did not name
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the precise day. Ever since the fulfilment of the prophecy, I have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: believed that Joan had the idea that her deliverance was going to come
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the form of death. But not that death! Divine as she was, dauntless
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: as she was in battle, she was human also. She was not solely a saint,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: an angel, she was a clay-made girl also--as human a girl as any in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the world, and full of a human girl's sensitiveness and tenderness and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: delicacies. And so, that death! No, she could not have lived the three
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: months with that one before her, I think. You remember that the first
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: time she was wounded she was frightened, and cried, just as any other
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: girl of seventeen would have done, although she had known for eighteen
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: days that she was going to be wounded on that very day. No, she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not afraid of any ordinary death, and an ordinary death was what she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: believed the prophecy of deliverance meant, I think, for her face showed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: happiness, not horror, when she uttered it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now I will explain why I think as I do. Five weeks before she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: captured in the battle of Compiegne, her Voices told her what was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: coming. They did not tell her the day or the place, but said she would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: be taken prisoner and that it would be before the feast of St. John.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She begged that death, certain and swift, should be her fate, and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: captivity brief; for she was a free spirit, and dreaded the confinement.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Voices made no promise, but only told her to bear whatever came. Now
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: as they did not refuse the swift death, a hopeful young thing like Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would naturally cherish that fact and make the most of it, allowing it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to grow and establish itself in her mind. And so now that she was told
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she was to be "delivered" in three months, I think she believed it meant
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that she would die in her bed in the prison, and that that was why she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: looked happy and content--the gates of Paradise standing open for her,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the time so short, you see, her troubles so soon to be over, her reward
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: so close at hand. Yes, that would make her look happy, that would make
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her patient and bold, and able to fight her fight out like a soldier.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Save herself if she could, of course, and try for the best, for that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was the way she was made; but die with her face to the front if die she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: must.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then later, when she charged Cauchon with trying to kill her with a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: poisoned fish, her notion that she was to be "delivered" by death in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: prison--if she had it, and I believe she had--would naturally be greatly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: strengthened, you see.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But I am wandering from the trial. Joan was asked to definitely name the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: time that she would be delivered from prison.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I have always said that I was not permitted to tell you everything. I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: am to be set free, and I desire to ask leave of my Voices to tell you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the day. That is why I wish for delay."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Do your Voices forbid you to tell the truth?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Is it that you wish to know matters concerning the King of France? I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tell you again that he will regain his kingdom, and that I know it as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: well as I know that you sit here before me in this tribunal." She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sighed and, after a little pause, added: "I should be dead but for this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: revelation, which comforts me always."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Some trivial questions were asked her about St. Michael's dress and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: appearance. She answered them with dignity, but one saw that they gave
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her pain. After a little she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I have great joy in seeing him, for when I see him I have the feeling
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that I am not in mortal sin."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She added, "Sometimes St. Marguerite and St. Catherine have allowed me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to confess myself to them."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Here was a possible chance to set a successful snare for her innocence.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "When you confessed were you in mortal sin, do you think?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But her reply did her no hurt. So the inquiry was shifted once more
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to the revelations made to the King--secrets which the court had tried
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: again and again to force out of Joan, but without success.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now as to the sign given to the King--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I have already told you that I will tell you nothing about it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Do you know what the sign was?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "As to that, you will not find out from me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: All this refers to Joan's secret interview with the King--held
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: apart, though two or three others were present. It was known--through
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Loyseleur, of course--that this sign was a crown and was a pledge of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: verity of Joan's mission. But that is all a mystery until this day--the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: nature of the crown, I mean--and will remain a mystery to the end of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: time. We can never know whether a real crown descended upon the King's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: head, or only a symbol, the mystic fabric of a vision.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Did you see a crown upon the King's head when he received the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: revelation?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I cannot tell you as to that, without perjury."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Did the King have that crown at Rheims?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I think the King put upon his head a crown which he found there; but a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: much richer one was brought him afterward."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Have you seen that one?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I cannot tell you, without perjury. But whether I have seen it or not,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I have heard say that it was rich and magnificent."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: They went on and pestered her to weariness about that mysterious crown,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but they got nothing more out of her. The sitting closed. A long, hard
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: day for all of us.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: 10 The Inquisitors at Their Wits' End
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: THE COURT rested a day, then took up work again on Saturday, the third
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of March.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: This was one of our stormiest sessions. The whole court was out
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of patience; and with good reason. These threescore distinguished
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: churchmen, illustrious tacticians, veteran legal gladiators, had left
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: important posts where their supervision was needed, to journey
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hither from various regions and accomplish a most simple and easy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: matter--condemn and send to death a country-lass of nineteen who could
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: neither read nor write, knew nothing of the wiles and perplexities of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: legal procedure, could not call a single witness in her defense, was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: allowed no advocate or adviser, and must conduct her case by herself
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: against a hostile judge and a packed jury. In two hours she would be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hopelessly entangled, routed, defeated, convicted. Nothing could be more
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: certain that this--so they thought. But it was a mistake. The two hours
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had strung out into days; what promised to be a skirmish had expanded
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: into a siege; the thing which had looked so easy had proven to be

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is the prerogative of Our Lord to choose His instruments where He
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: will."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was asked what form of prayer she used in invoking counsel from on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: high. She said the form was brief and simple; then she lifted her pallid
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: face and repeated it, clasping her chained hands:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Most dear God, in honor of your holy passion I beseech you, if you love
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: me, that you will reveal to me what I am to answer to these churchmen.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: As concerns my dress, I know by what command I have put it on, but I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: know not in what manner I am to lay it off. I pray you tell me what to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: do."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was charged with having dared, against the precepts of God and His
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: saints, to assume empire over men and make herself Commander-in-Chief.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: That touched the soldier in her. She had a deep reverence for priests,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but the soldier in her had but small reverence for a priest's opinions
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: about war; so, in her answer to this charge she did not condescend to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: go into any explanations or excuses, but delivered herself with bland
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: indifference and military brevity.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If I was Commander-in-Chief, it was to thrash the English."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Death was staring her in the face here all the time, but no matter;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she dearly loved to make these English-hearted Frenchmen squirm, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: whenever they gave her an opening she was prompt to jab her sting into
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it. She got great refreshment out of these little episodes. Her days
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: were a desert; these were the oases in it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Her being in the wars with men was charged against her as an indelicacy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I had a woman with me when I could--in towns and lodgings. In the field
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I always slept in my armor."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: That she and her family had been ennobled by the King was charged
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: against her as evidence that the source of her deeds were sordid
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: self-seeking. She answered that she had not asked this grace of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: King; it was his own act.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: This third trial was ended at last. And once again there was no definite
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: result.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Possibly a fourth trial might succeed in defeating this apparently
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: unconquerable girl. So the malignant Bishop set himself to work to plan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: He appointed a commission to reduce the substance of the sixty-six
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: articles to twelve compact lies, as a basis for the new attempt. This
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was done. It took several days.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Meantime Cauchon went to Joan's cell one day, with Manchon and two of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the judges, Isambard de la Pierre and Martin Ladvenue, to see if he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could not manage somehow to beguile Joan into submitting her mission to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the examination and decision of the Church Militant--that is to say, to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that part of the Church Militant which was represented by himself and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: his creatures.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan once more positively refused. Isambard de la Pierre had a heart in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: his body, and he so pitied this persecuted poor girl that he ventured to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: do a very daring thing; for he asked her if she would be willing to have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her case go before the Council of Basel, and said it contained as many
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: priests of her party as of the English party.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan cried out that she would gladly go before so fairly constructed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a tribunal as that; but before Isambard could say another word Cauchon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: turned savagely upon him and exclaimed:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Shut up, in the devil's name!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then Manchon ventured to do a brave thing, too, though he did it in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: great fear for his life. He asked Cauchon if he should enter Joan's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: submission to the Council of Basel upon the minutes.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No! It is not necessary."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah," said poor Joan, reproachfully, "you set down everything that is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: against me, but you will not set down what is for me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was piteous. It would have touched the heart of a brute. But Cauchon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was more than that.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark
