text: 14 Joan Struggles with Her Twelve Lies
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: WE WERE now in the first days of April. Joan was ill. She had fallen ill
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the 29th of March, the day after the close of the third trial, and was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: growing worse when the scene which I have just described occurred in her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: cell. It was just like Cauchon to go there and try to get some advantage
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: out of her weakened state.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Let us note some of the particulars in the new indictment--the Twelve
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Lies.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Part of the first one says Joan asserts that she has found her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: salvation. She never said anything of the kind. It also says she refuses
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to submit herself to the Church. Not true. She was willing to submit all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her acts to this Rouen tribunal except those done by the command of God
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in fulfilment of her mission. Those she reserved for the judgment of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: God. She refused to recognize Cauchon and his serfs as the Church, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was willing to go before the Pope or the Council of Basel.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: A clause of another of the Twelve says she admits having threatened with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: death those who would not obey her. Distinctly false. Another clause
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: says she declares that all she has done has been done by command of God.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: What she really said was, all that she had done well--a correction made
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: by herself as you have already seen.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Another of the Twelve says she claims that she has never committed any
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sin. She never made any such claim.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Another makes the wearing of the male dress a sin. If it was, she had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: high Catholic authority for committing it--that of the Archbishop of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Rheims and the tribunal of Poitiers.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Tenth Article was resentful against her for "pretending" that St.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Catherine and St.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Marguerite spoke French and not English, and were French in their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: politics.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Twelve were to be submitted first to the learned doctors of theology
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the University of Paris for approval. They were copied out and ready
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: by the night of April 4th. Then Manchon did another bold thing: he wrote
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the margin that many of the Twelve put statements in Joan's mouth
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: which were the exact opposite of what she had said. That fact would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not be considered important by the University of Paris, and would not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: influence its decision or stir its humanity, in case it had any--which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it hadn't when acting in a political capacity, as at present--but it was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a brave thing for that good Manchon to do, all the same.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Twelve were sent to Paris next day, April 5th. That afternoon there
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was a great tumult in Rouen, and excited crowds were flocking through
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: all the chief streets, chattering and seeking for news; for a report had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: gone abroad that Joan of Arc was sick until death. In truth, these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: long seances had worn her out, and she was ill indeed. The heads of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: English party were in a state of consternation; for if Joan should die
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: uncondemned by the Church and go to the grave unsmirched, the pity and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the love of the people would turn her wrongs and sufferings and death
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: into a holy martyrdom, and she would be even a mightier power in France
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dead than she had been when alive.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Earl of Warwick and the English Cardinal (Winchester) hurried to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the castle and sent messengers flying for physicians. Warwick was a hard
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: man, a rude, coarse man, a man without compassion. There lay the sick
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: girl stretched in her chains in her iron cage--not an object to move man
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to ungentle speech, one would think; yet Warwick spoke right out in her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hearing and said to the physicians:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Mind you take good care of her. The King of England has no mind to have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her die a natural death. She is dear to him, for he bought her dear, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: he does not want her to die, save at the stake. Now then, mind you cure
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The doctors asked Joan what had made her ill. She said the Bishop of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Beauvais had sent her a fish and she thought it was that.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then Jean d'Estivet burst out on her, and called her names and abused
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her. He understood Joan to be charging the Bishop with poisoning her,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: you see; and that was not pleasing to him, for he was one of Cauchon's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: most loving and conscienceless slaves, and it outraged him to have Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: injure his master in the eyes of these great English chiefs, these being
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: men who could ruin Cauchon and would promptly do it if they got
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the conviction that he was capable of saving Joan from the stake by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: poisoning her and thus cheating the English out of all the real value
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: gainable by her purchase from the Duke of Burgundy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan had a high fever, and the doctors proposed to bleed her. Warwick
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Be careful about that; she is smart and is capable of killing herself."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: He meant that to escape the stake she might undo the bandage and let
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: herself bleed to death.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But the doctors bled her anyway, and then she was better.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Not for long, though. Jean d'Estivet could not hold still, he was so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: worried and angry about the suspicion of poisoning which Joan had hinted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: at; so he came back in the evening and stormed at her till he brought
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the fever all back again.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: When Warwick heard of this he was in a fine temper, you may be sure,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: for here was his prey threatening to escape again, and all through
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the over-zeal of this meddling fool. Warwick gave D'Estivet a quite
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: admirable cursing--admirable as to strength, I mean, for it was said by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: persons of culture that the art of it was not good--and after that the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: meddler kept still.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan remained ill more than two weeks; then she grew better. She was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: still very weak, but she could bear a little persecution now without
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: much danger to her life. It seemed to Cauchon a good time to furnish it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: So he called together some of his doctors of theology and went to her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dungeon. Manchon and I went along to keep the record--that is, to set
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: down what might be useful to Cauchon, and leave out the rest.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The sight of Joan gave me a shock. Why, she was but a shadow! It was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: difficult for me to realize that this frail little creature with the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sad face and drooping form was the same Joan of Arc that I had so often
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: seen, all fire and enthusiasm, charging through a hail of death and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the lightning and thunder of the guns at the head of her battalions. It
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: wrung my heart to see her looking like this.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But Cauchon was not touched. He made another of those conscienceless
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: speeches of his, all dripping with hypocrisy and guile. He told Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that among her answers had been some which had seemed to endanger
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: religion; and as she was ignorant and without knowledge of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Scriptures, he had brought some good and wise men to instruct her, if
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she desired it. Said he, "We are churchmen, and disposed by our good
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: will as well as by our vocation to procure for you the salvation of your
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: soul and your body, in every way in our power, just as we would do the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: like for our nearest kin or for ourselves. In this we but follow the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: example of Holy Church, who never closes the refuge of her bosom against
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: any that are willing to return."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan thanked him for these sayings and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I seem to be in danger of death from this malady; if it be the pleasure

text: valuable knowledge and all wisdom, the University of Paris, were still
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: weighing and considering and discussing the Twelve Lies.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I had had but little to do these ten days, so I spent them mainly in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: walks about the town with Noel. But there was no pleasure in them, our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: spirits being so burdened with cares, and the outlook for Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: growing steadily darker and darker all the time. And then we naturally
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: contrasted our circumstances with hers: this freedom and sunshine, with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her darkness and chains; our comradeship, with her lonely estate; our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: alleviations of one sort and another, with her destitution in all.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was used to liberty, but now she had none; she was an out-of-door
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: creature by nature and habit, but now she was shut up day and night in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a steel cage like an animal; she was used to the light, but now she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: always in a gloom where all objects about her were dim and spectral; she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was used to the thousand various sounds which are the cheer and music
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of a busy life, but now she heard only the monotonous footfall of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sentry pacing his watch; she had been fond of talking with her mates,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but now there was no one to talk to; she had had an easy laugh, but it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was gone dumb now; she had been born for comradeship, and blithe and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: busy work, and all manner of joyous activities, but here were only
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dreariness, and leaden hours, and weary inaction, and brooding
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: stillness, and thoughts that travel by day and night and night and day
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: round and round in the same circle, and wear the brain and break the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heart with weariness. It was death in life; yes, death in life, that is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: what it must have been. And there was another hard thing about it all. A
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: young girl in trouble needs the soothing solace and support and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sympathy of persons of her own sex, and the delicate offices and gentle
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ministries which only these can furnish; yet in all these months of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: gloomy captivity in her dungeon Joan never saw the face of a girl or a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: woman. Think how her heart would have leaped to see such a face.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Consider. If you would realize how great Joan of Arc was, remember that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was out of such a place and such circumstances that she came week
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: after week and month after month and confronted the master intellects
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of France single-handed, and baffled their cunningest schemes, defeated
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: their ablest plans, detected and avoided their secretest traps and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pitfalls, broke their lines, repelled their assaults, and camped on the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: field after every engagement; steadfast always, true to her faith and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her ideals; defying torture, defying the stake, and answering threats
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of eternal death and the pains of hell with a simple "Let come what may,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: here I take my stand and will abide."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, if you would realize how great was the soul, how profound the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: wisdom, and how luminous the intellect of Joan of Arc, you must study
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her there, where she fought out that long fight all alone--and not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: merely against the subtlest brains and deepest learning of France, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: against the ignoble deceits, the meanest treacheries, and the hardest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hearts to be found in any land, pagan or Christian.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was great in battle--we all know that; great in foresight; great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in loyalty and patriotism; great in persuading discontented chiefs and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: reconciling conflicting interests and passions; great in the ability to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: discover merit and genius wherever it lay hidden; great in picturesque
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and eloquent speech; supremely great in the gift of firing the hearts
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of hopeless men and noble enthusiasms, the gift of turning hares into
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heroes, slaves and skulkers into battalions that march to death with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: songs on their lips. But all these are exalting activities; they keep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hand and heart and brain keyed up to their work; there is the joy of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: achievement, the inspiration of stir and movement, the applause which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hails success; the soul is overflowing with life and energy, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: faculties are at white heat; weariness, despondency, inertia--these do
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not exist.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, Joan of Arc was great always, great everywhere, but she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: greatest in the Rouen trials.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: There she rose above the limitations and infirmities of our human
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: nature, and accomplished under blighting and unnerving and hopeless
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: conditions all that her splendid equipment of moral and intellectual
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: forces could have accomplished if they had been supplemented by the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mighty helps of hope and cheer and light, the presence of friendly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: faces, and a fair and equal fight, with the great world looking on and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: wondering.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 18 Condemned Yet Unafraid
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: TOWARD THE END of the ten-day interval the University of Paris rendered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: its decision concerning the Twelve Articles. By this finding, Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was guilty upon all the counts: she must renounce her errors and make
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: satisfaction, or be abandoned to the secular arm for punishment.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The University's mind was probably already made up before the Articles
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: were laid before it; yet it took it from the fifth to the eighteenth to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: produce its verdict. I think the delay may have been caused by temporary
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: difficulties concerning two points:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 1. As to who the fiends were who were represented in Joan's Voices; 2.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: As to whether her saints spoke French only.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: You understand, the University decided emphatically that it was fiends
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: who spoke in those Voices; it would need to prove that, and it did. It
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: found out who those fiends were, and named them in the verdict: Belial,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Satan, and Behemoth. This has always seemed a doubtful thing to me,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and not entitled to much credit. I think so for this reason: if the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: University had actually known it was those three, it would for very
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: consistency's sake have told how it knew it, and not stopped with the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mere assertion, since it had made Joan explain how she knew they were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not fiends. Does not that seem reasonable? To my mind the University's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: position was weak, and I will tell you why. It had claimed that Joan's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: angels were devils in disguise, and we all know that devils do disguise
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: themselves as angels; up to that point the University's position was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong; but you see yourself that it eats its own argument when it turns
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: around and pretends that it can tell who such apparitions are, while
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: denying the like ability to a person with as good a head on her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: shoulders as the best one the University could produce.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The doctors of the University had to see those creatures in order to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: know; and if Joan was deceived, it is argument that they in their turn
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: could also be deceived, for their insight and judgment were surely not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: clearer than hers.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: As to the other point which I have thought may have proved a difficulty
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and cost the University delay, I will touch but a moment upon that, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pass on. The University decided that it was blasphemy for Joan to say
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that her saints spoke French and not English, and were on the French
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: side in political sympathies. I think that the thing which troubled the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: doctors of theology was this: they had decided that the three Voices
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: were Satan and two other devils; but they had also decided that these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Voices were not on the French side--thereby tacitly asserting that they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: were on the English side; and if on the English side, then they must be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: angels and not devils. Otherwise, the situation was embarrassing. You
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: see, the University being the wisest and deepest and most erudite body
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the world, it would like to be logical if it could, for the sake
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of its reputation; therefore it would study and study, days and days,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: trying to find some good common-sense reason for proving the Voices to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: be devils in Article No. 1 and proving them to be angels in Article No.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 10. However, they had to give it up. They found no way out; and so, to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: this day, the University's verdict remains just so--devils in No. 1,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: angels in No. 10; and no way to reconcile the discrepancy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The envoys brought the verdict to Rouen, and with it a letter for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon which was full of fervid praise. The University complimented
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: him on his zeal in hunting down this woman "whose venom had infected the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: faithful of the whole West," and as recompense it as good as promised
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: him "a crown of imperishable glory in heaven." Only that!--a crown in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: heaven; a promissory note and no indorser; always something away off
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: yonder; not a word about the Archbishopric of Rouen, which was the thing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon was destroying his soul for. A crown in heaven; it must have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sounded like a sarcasm to him, after all his hard work. What should he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: do in heaven? he did not know anybody there.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: On the nineteenth of May a court of fifty judges sat in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: archiepiscopal palace to discuss Joan's fate. A few wanted her delivered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: over to the secular arm at once for punishment, but the rest insisted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that she be once more "charitably admonished" first.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: So the same court met in the castle on the twenty-third, and Joan was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: brought to the bar. Pierre Maurice, a canon of Rouen, made a speech
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to Joan in which he admonished her to save her life and her soul by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: renouncing her errors and surrendering to the Church. He finished with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a stern threat: if she remained obstinate the damnation of her soul was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: certain, the destruction of her body probable. But Joan was immovable.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If I were under sentence, and saw the fire before me, and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: executioner ready to light it--more, if I were in the fire itself, I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would say none but the things which I have said in these trials; and I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would abide by them till I died."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: A deep silence followed now, which endured some moments. It lay upon me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: like a weight. I knew it for an omen. Then Cauchon, grave and solemn,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: turned to Pierre Maurice:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Have you anything further to say?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The priest bowed low, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Nothing, my lord."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Prisoner at the bar, have you anything further to say?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Nothing."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Then the debate is closed. To-morrow, sentence will be pronounced.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Remove the prisoner."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She seemed to go from the place erect and noble. But I do not know; my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sight was dim with tears.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: To-morrow--twenty-fourth of May! Exactly a year since I saw her go
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: speeding across the plain at the head of her troops, her silver helmet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: shining, her silvery cape fluttering in the wind, her white plumes
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: flowing, her sword held aloft; saw her charge the Burgundian camp three
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: times, and carry it; saw her wheel to the right and spur for the duke's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: reserves; saw her fling herself against it in the last assault she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ever to make. And now that fatal day was come again--and see what it was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bringing!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: 19 Our Last Hopes of Rescue Fail
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: JOAN HAD been adjudged guilty of heresy, sorcery, and all the other
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: terrible crimes set forth in the Twelve Articles, and her life was in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cauchon's hands at last. He could send her to the stake at once. His
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: work was finished now, you think? He was satisfied? Not at all. What
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would his Archbishopric be worth if the people should get the idea into
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: their heads that this faction of interested priests, slaving under the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: English lash, had wrongly condemned and burned Joan of Arc, Deliverer
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of France? That would be to make of her a holy martyr. Then her spirit
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would rise from her body's ashes, a thousandfold reinforced, and sweep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the English domination into the sea, and Cauchon along with it. No,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the victory was not complete yet. Joan's guilt must be established by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: evidence which would satisfy the people. Where was that evidence to be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: found? There was only one person in the world who could furnish it--Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of Arc herself. She must condemn herself, and in public--at least she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: must seem to do it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: But how was this to be managed? Weeks had been spent already in trying
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: She had herself taught them what to do, you see. First, they must wear
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: and trick her into signing that.

author: Twain, Mark

text: Yet there was still one other difficulty. If they made her seem to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: That would not answer; for only her death would content the English.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: the stake would be ready.

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of priest, friend, and secret partisan of France and hater of England,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: thing"--submit to the Church, as a good Christian should; and that then

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: IN THE MORNING I was at my official post. It was on a platform raised
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the height of a man, in the churchyard, under the eaves of St. Ouen. On
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: this same platform was a crowd of priests and important citizens, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: several lawyers. Abreast it, with a small space between, was another and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: larger platform, handsomely canopied against sun and rain, and richly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: carpeted; also it was furnished with comfortable chairs, and with two
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: level. One of these two was occupied by a prince of the royal blood of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: England, his Eminence the Cardinal of Winchester; the other by Cauchon,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Vice-Inquisitor, eight abbots, and the sixty-two friars and lawyers who
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had sat as Joan's judges in her late trials.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that. We seem so delicately made, so destructible, so insubstantial; yet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

text: such solacement as the thought could furnish, that by another clear
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: promise made by Cauchon himself--she would at least be the Church's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: captive, and have women about her in place of a brutal foreign soldiery.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mocking laugh:

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Poor abused girl! She stood dumb, smitten, paralyzed. It was pitiful to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

text: deep game which Cauchon was playing except the Cardinal of Winchester.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: waiting, all this tantalizing expectancy.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: He a traitor! Oh, far from it; he certainly was the last Frenchman that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: any Briton had a right to bring that charge against.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Earl of Warwick lost his temper, too. He was a doughty soldier, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: when it came to the intellectuals--when it came to delicate chicane, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: than another. So he burst out in his frank warrior fashion, and swore
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Perhaps the like tidings found their way all around, for good news
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: travels fast as well as bad. At any rate, the ragings presently quieted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: down, and the huge concourse crumbled apart and disappeared. And thus we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We two youths were happy; happier than any words can tell--for we were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not in the secret any more than the rest. Joan's life was saved. We
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: knew that, and that was enough. France would hear of this day's infamous
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: by thousands and thousands, multitudes upon multitudes, and their wrath
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: again!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: For we were young then, yes, we were very young.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: No, there was no rest for her, with those sleuth-hounds on her track.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: about.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: on the march--France at the gates--Rouen in ashes, and Joan free! Our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: were very young, as I have said.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: now, and her captivity made as pleasant and comfortable for her as the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: share in the great rescue, and fought our part of the fight over and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: known.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: thinking. Thinking of the rescue--what else? I had no other thought now.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was absorbed in that, drunk with the happiness of it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I heard a voice shouting far down the street, and soon it came nearer,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and I caught the words:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: years ago, but that triumphant note rings as clear in my memory to-day
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: as it rang in my ear that long-vanished summer morning. We are so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the memories that break our hearts that abide.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: thanksgiving.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tumultuous tides of furious men billowing by along the street.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: lives.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

text: and so submit to the will of God; and in thus obeying, find assuagement
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of our grief. It was like her, for she was always thinking of others,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not of herself. Yes, her heart was sore for us; she could find time to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: think of us, the humblest of her servants, and try to soften our pain,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: lighten the burden of our troubles--she that was drinking of the bitter
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: waters; she that was walking in the Valley of the Shadow of Death.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I wrote the letter. You will know what it cost me, without my telling
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: you. I wrote it with the same wooden stylus which had put upon parchment
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the first words ever dictated by Joan of Arc--that high summons to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the English to vacate France, two years past, when she was a lass of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: seventeen; it had now set down the last ones which she was ever to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dictate. Then I broke it. For the pen that had served Joan of Arc could
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: not serve any that would come after her in this earth without abasement.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark
