author: Twain, Mark

text: The next day, May 29th, Cauchon summoned his serfs, and forty-two
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: responded. It is charitable to believe that the other twenty were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: ashamed to come. The forty-two pronounced her a relapsed heretic, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: condemned her to be delivered over to the secular arm. Cauchon thanked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: them.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then he sent orders that Joan of Arc be conveyed the next morning to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the place known as the Old Market; and that she be then delivered to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: civil judge, and by the civil judge to the executioner. That meant she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: would be burnt.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: All the afternoon and evening of Tuesday, the 29th, the news was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: flying, and the people of the country-side flocking to Rouen to see the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tragedy--all, at least, who could prove their English sympathies and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: count upon admission. The press grew thicker and thicker in the streets,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the excitement grew higher and higher. And now a thing was noticeable
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: again which had been noticeable more than once before--that there was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pity for Joan in the hearts of many of these people. Whenever she had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: been in great danger it had manifested itself, and now it was apparent
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: again--manifest in a pathetic dumb sorrow which was visible in many
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: faces.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Early the next morning, Wednesday, Martin Ladvenu and another friar
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: were sent to Joan to prepare her for death; and Manchon and I went
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with them--a hard service for me. We tramped through the dim corridors,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: winding this way and that, and piercing ever deeper and deeper into that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: vast heart of stone, and at last we stood before Joan. But she did not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: know it. She sat with her hands in her lap and her head bowed, thinking,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and her face was very sad. One might not know what she was thinking of.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Of her home, and the peaceful pastures, and the friends she was no more
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to see? Of her wrongs, and her forsaken estate, and the cruelties which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had been put upon her? Or was it of death--the death which she had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: longed for, and which was now so close?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Or was it of the kind of death she must suffer? I hoped not; for she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: feared only one kind, and that one had for her unspeakable terrors. I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: believed she so feared that one that with her strong will she would shut
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the thought of it wholly out of her mind, and hope and believe that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: God would take pity on her and grant her an easier one; and so it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: might chance that the awful news which we were bringing might come as a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: surprise to her at last.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: We stood silent awhile, but she was still unconscious of us, still deep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: in her sad musings and far away. Then Martin Ladvenu said, softly:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She looked up then, with a little start and a wan smile, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Speak. Have you a message for me?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, my poor child. Try to bear it. Do you think you can bear it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes"--very softly, and her head drooped again.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I am come to prepare you for death."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: A faint shiver trembled through her wasted body. There was a pause. In
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the stillness we could hear our breathings. Then she said, still in that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: low voice:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "When will it be?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The muffled notes of a tolling bell floated to our ears out of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: distance.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now. The time is at hand."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: That slight shiver passed again.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is so soon--ah, it is so soon!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was a long silence. The distant throbbings of the bell pulsed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: through it, and we stood motionless and listening. But it was broken at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: last:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What death is it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "By fire!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, I knew it, I knew it!" She sprang wildly to her feet, and wound her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hands in her hair, and began to writhe and sob, oh, so piteously, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mourn and grieve and lament, and turn to first one and then another of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: us, and search our faces beseechingly, as hoping she might find help and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: friendliness there, poor thing--she that had never denied these to any
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: creature, even her wounded enemy on the battle-field.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, cruel, cruel, to treat me so! And must my body, that has never been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: defiled, be consumed today and turned to ashes? Ah, sooner would I that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: my head were cut off seven times than suffer this woeful death. I had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the promise of the Church's prison when I submitted, and if I had but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: been there, and not left here in the hands of my enemies, this miserable
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fate had not befallen me.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, I appeal to God the Great Judge, against the injustice which has
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: been done me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was none there that could endure it. They turned away, with the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tears running down their faces. In a moment I was on my knees at her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: feet. At once she thought only of my danger, and bent and whispered in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: my hear: "Up!--do not peril yourself, good heart. There--God bless you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: always!" and I felt the quick clasp of her hand. Mine was the last hand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she touched with hers in life. None saw it; history does not know of it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: or tell of it, yet it is true, just as I have told it. The next moment
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: she saw Cauchon coming, and she went and stood before him and reproached
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: him, saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Bishop, it is by you that I die!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: He was not shamed, not touched; but said, smoothly:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, be patient, Joan. You die because you have not kept your promise,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but have returned to your sins."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Alas," she said, "if you had put me in the Church's prison, and given
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: me right and proper keepers, as you promised, this would not have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: happened. And for this I summon you to answer before God!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then Cauchon winced, and looked less placidly content than before, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: he turned him about and went away.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan stood awhile musing. She grew calmer, but occasionally she wiped
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her eyes, and now and then sobs shook her body; but their violence
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was modifying now, and the intervals between them were growing longer.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Finally she looked up and saw Pierre Maurice, who had come in with the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Bishop, and she said to him:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Master Peter, where shall I be this night?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Have you not good hope in God?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes--and by His grace I shall be in Paradise."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now Martin Ladvenu heard her in confession; then she begged for the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sacrament. But how grant the communion to one who had been publicly cut
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: off from the Church, and was now no more entitled to its privileges
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: than an unbaptized pagan? The brother could not do this, but he sent
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to Cauchon to inquire what he must do. All laws, human and divine, were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: alike to that man--he respected none of them. He sent back orders to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: grant Joan whatever she wished. Her last speech to him had reached his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fears, perhaps; it could not reach his heart, for he had none.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Eucharist was brought now to that poor soul that had yearned for it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with such unutterable longing all these desolate months. It was a solemn
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: moment. While we had been in the deeps of the prison, the public courts
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: They stood elbow to elbow, on each side of Joan's road, and walled it in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: all the way; and behind these living walls knelt the multitudes.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: By and by a frantic man in priest's garb came wailing and lamenting, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: tore through the crowd and the barriers of soldiers and flung himself
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: on his knees by Joan's cart and put up his hands in supplication, crying
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: out:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "O forgive, forgive!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was Loyseleur!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And Joan forgave him; forgave him out of a heart that knew nothing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but forgiveness, nothing but compassion, nothing but pity for all that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: suffer, let their offense be what it might. And she had no word of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: reproach for this poor wretch who had wrought day and night with deceits
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and treacheries and hypocrisies to betray her to her death.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The soldiers would have killed him, but the Earl of Warwick saved his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: life. What became of him is not known. He hid himself from the world
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: somewhere, to endure his remorse as he might.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: In the square of the Old Market stood the two platforms and the stake
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that had stood before in the churchyard of St. Ouen. The platforms were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: occupied as before, the one by Joan and her judges, the other by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: great dignitaries, the principal being Cauchon and the English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cardinal--Winchester. The square was packed with people, the windows and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: roofs of the blocks of buildings surrounding it were black with them.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: When the preparations had been finished, all noise and movement
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: gradually ceased, and a waiting stillness followed which was solemn and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: impressive.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And now, by order of Cauchon, an ecclesiastic named Nicholas Midi
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: preached a sermon, wherein he explained that when a branch of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: vine--which is the Church--becomes diseased and corrupt, it must be cut
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: away or it will corrupt and destroy the whole vine. He made it appear
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that Joan, through her wickedness, was a menace and a peril to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Church's purity and holiness, and her death therefore necessary. When he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was come to the end of his discourse he turned toward her and paused a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: moment, then he said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, the Church can no longer protect you. Go in peace!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan had been placed wholly apart and conspicuous, to signify the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Church's abandonment of her, and she sat there in her loneliness,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: waiting in patience and resignation for the end. Cauchon addressed her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: now. He had been advised to read the form of her abjuration to her, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: had brought it with him; but he changed his mind, fearing that she would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: proclaim the truth--that she had never knowingly abjured--and so bring
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: shame upon him and eternal infamy. He contented himself with admonishing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her to keep in mind her wickednesses, and repent of them, and think of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: her salvation. Then he solemnly pronounced her excommunicate and cut off
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: from the body of the Church. With a final word he delivered her over to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the secular arm for judgment and sentence.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan, weeping, knelt and began to pray. For whom? Herself? Oh, no--for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the King of France. Her voice rose sweet and clear, and penetrated all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: hearts with its passionate pathos. She never thought of his treacheries
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to her, she never thought of his desertion of her, she never remembered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that it was because he was an ingrate that she was here to die a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: miserable death; she remembered only that he was her King, that she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: his loyal and loving subject, and that his enemies had undermined his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: cause with evil reports and false charges, and he not by to defend
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: himself. And so, in the very presence of death, she forgot her own
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: troubles to implore all in her hearing to be just to him; to believe
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that he was good and noble and sincere, and not in any way to blame
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: for any acts of hers, neither advising them nor urging them, but being
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: wholly clear and free of all responsibility for them. Then, closing, she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: begged in humble and touching words that all here present would pray
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: for her and would pardon her, both her enemies and such as might look
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: friendly upon her and feel pity for her in their hearts.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was hardly one heart there that was not touched--even the English,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: even the judges showed it, and there was many a lip that trembled
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and many an eye that was blurred with tears; yes, even the English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Cardinal's--that man with a political heart of stone but a human heart
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of flesh.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The secular judge who should have delivered judgment and pronounced
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sentence was himself so disturbed that he forgot his duty, and Joan went
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to her death unsentenced--thus completing with an illegality what had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: begun illegally and had so continued to the end. He only said--to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: guards:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Take her"; and to the executioner, "Do your duty."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan asked for a cross. None was able to furnish one. But an English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: soldier broke a stick in two and crossed the pieces and tied them
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: together, and this cross he gave her, moved to it by the good heart that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was in him; and she kissed it and put it in her bosom. Then Isambard de
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: la Pierre went to the church near by and brought her a consecrated one;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and this one also she kissed, and pressed it to her bosom with rapture,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and then kissed it again and again, covering it with tears and pouring
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: out her gratitude to God and the saints.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: And so, weeping, and with her cross to her lips, she climbed up the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: cruel steps to the face of the stake, with the friar Isambard at her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: side. Then she was helped up to the top of the pile of wood that was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: built around the lower third of the stake and stood upon it with her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: back against the stake, and the world gazing up at her breathless. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: executioner ascended to her side and wound chains around her slender
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: body, and so fastened her to the stake. Then he descended to finish his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dreadful office; and there she remained alone--she that had had so many
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: friends in the days when she was free, and had been so loved and so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: dear.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: All these things I saw, albeit dimly and blurred with tears; but I could
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bear no more. I continued in my place, but what I shall deliver to you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: now I got by others' eyes and others' mouths. Tragic sounds there were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that pierced my ears and wounded my heart as I sat there, but it is as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I tell you: the latest image recorded by my eyes in that desolating hour
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was Joan of Arc with the grace of her comely youth still unmarred; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that image, untouched by time or decay, has remained with me all my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: days. Now I will go on.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: If any thought that now, in that solemn hour when all transgressors
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: repent and confess, she would revoke her revocation and say her great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: deeds had been evil deeds and Satan and his fiends their source, they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: erred. No such thought was in her blameless mind. She was not thinking
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of herself and her troubles, but of others, and of woes that might
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: befall them. And so, turning her grieving eyes about her, where rose the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: towers and spires of that fair city, she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, Rouen, Rouen, must I die here, and must you be my tomb? Ah, Rouen,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Rouen, I have great fear that you will suffer for my death."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: A whiff of smoke swept upward past her face, and for one moment terror
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: seized her and she cried out, "Water! Give me holy water!" but the next
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: moment her fears were gone, and they came no more to torture her.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She heard the flames crackling below her, and immediately distress for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: a fellow-creature who was in danger took possession of her. It was the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: friar Isambard. She had given him her cross and begged him to raise it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: toward her face and let her eyes rest in hope and consolation upon it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: till she was entered into the peace of God. She made him go out from the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: danger of the fire. Then she was satisfied, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now keep it always in my sight until the end."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Not even yet could Cauchon, that man without shame, endure to let her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: die in peace, but went toward her, all black with crimes and sins as he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was, and cried out:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I am come, Joan, to exhort you for the last time to repent and seek the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pardon of God."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I die through you," she said, and these were the last words she spoke
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to any upon earth.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: up in a thick volume and hid her from sight; and from the heart of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: form, and the voice was still.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pastures the time that she said the rest of us would go to the great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: wars.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: he died.

author: Twain, Mark

text: she lived out her days, which were many. Twenty-four years after her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: illustrious child's death she traveled all the way to Paris in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: winter-time and was present at the opening of the discussion in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sight of the venerable dame, and it was a touching spectacle when she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

text: but war-torn veterans with hair beginning to show frost.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2

author: Twain, Mark

text: the Rehabilitation. But they are all at rest now, these many years.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I alone am left of those who fought at the side of Joan of Arc in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: great wars.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: She said I would live until those wars were forgotten--a prophecy which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: failed. If I should live a thousand years it would still fail. For
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: whatsoever had touch with Joan of Arc, that thing is immortal.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Members of Joan's family married, and they have left descendants. Their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: descendants are of the nobility, but their family name and blood bring
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: them honors which no other nobles receive or may hope for. You have seen
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: how everybody along the way uncovered when those children came yesterday
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: to pay their duty to me. It was not because they are noble, it is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: because they are grandchildren of the brothers of Joan of Arc.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now as to the Rehabilitation. Joan crowned the King at Rheims. For
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: reward he allowed her to be hunted to her death without making one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: effort to save her. During the next twenty-three years he remained
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: indifferent to her memory; indifferent to the fact that her good name
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was under a damning blot put there by the priest because of the deeds
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: which she had done in saving him and his scepter; indifferent to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fact that France was ashamed, and longed to have the Deliverer's fair
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fame restored. Indifferent all that time. Then he suddenly changed and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was anxious to have justice for poor Joan himself. Why? Had he become
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: grateful at last? Had remorse attacked his hard heart? No, he had a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: better reason--a better one for his sort of man. This better reason was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that, now that the English had been finally expelled from the country,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: they were beginning to call attention to the fact that this King had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: gotten his crown by the hands of a person proven by the priests to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: have been in league with Satan and burned for it by them as a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sorceress--therefore, of what value or authority was such a Kingship as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: that? Of no value at all; no nation could afford to allow such a king to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: remain on the throne.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was high time to stir now, and the King did it. That is how Charles
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: VII. came to be smitten with anxiety to have justice done the memory of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: his benefactress.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: He appealed to the Pope, and the Pope appointed a great commission of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: churchmen to examine into the facts of Joan's life and award judgment.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Commission sat at Paris, at Domremy, at Rouen, at Orleans, and at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: several other places, and continued its work during several months.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It examined the records of Joan's trials, it examined the Bastard
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: of Orleans, and the Duke d'Alencon, and D'Aulon, and Pasquerel, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Courcelles, and Isambard de la Pierre, and Manchon, and me, and many
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: others whose names I have made familiar to you; also they examined
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: more than a hundred witnesses whose names are less familiar to you--the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: friends of Joan in Domremy, Vaucouleurs, Orleans, and other places,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and a number of judges and other people who had assisted at the Rouen
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: trials, the abjuration, and the martyrdom. And out of this exhaustive
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: examination Joan's character and history came spotless and perfect, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: this verdict was placed upon record, to remain forever.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was present upon most of these occasions, and saw again many faces
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: which I have not seen for a quarter of a century; among them some
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: well-beloved faces--those of our generals and that of Catherine Boucher
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: (married, alas!), and also among them certain other faces that filled me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with bitterness--those of Beaupere and Courcelles and a number of their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fellow-fiends. I saw Haumette and Little Mengette--edging along toward
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: fifty now, and mothers of many children. I saw Noel's father, and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: parents of the Paladin and the Sunflower.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was beautiful to hear the Duke d'Alencon praise Joan's splendid
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: capacities as a general, and to hear the Bastard indorse these praises
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: with his eloquent tongue and then go on and tell how sweet and good Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: was, and how full of pluck and fire and impetuosity, and mischief, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: mirthfulness, and tenderness, and compassion, and everything that was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: pure and fine and noble and lovely. He made her live again before me,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and wrung my heart.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: I have finished my story of Joan of Arc, that wonderful child, that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: sublime personality, that spirit which in one regard has had no peer
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: and will have none--this: its purity from all alloy of self-seeking,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: self-interest, personal ambition. In it no trace of these motives can
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: be found, search as you may, and this cannot be said of any other person
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: whose name appears in profane history.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: With Joan of Arc love of country was more than a sentiment--it was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: passion. She was the Genius of Patriotism--she was Patriotism embodied,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: concreted, made flesh, and palpable to the touch and visible to the eye.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: Love, Mercy, Charity, Fortitude, War, Peace, Poetry, Music--these may be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: symbolized as any shall prefer: by figures of either sex and of any age;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: but a slender girl in her first young bloom, with the martyr's crown
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon her head, and in her hand the sword that severed her country's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: bonds--shall not this, and no other, stand for PATRIOTISM through all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

text: the ages until time shall end?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 2
author: Twain, Mark
